<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">South Korea</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in East Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"Republic of Korea" and "Daehanminguk" redirect here. For the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, see <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. For the government in exile that used the same name, see <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_Republic_of_Korea" title="Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea">Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea</a>.</div>
<p>
<span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1073938472">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=South_Korea&amp;params=36_N_128_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">36°N</span> <span class="longitude">128°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">36°N 128°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">36; 128</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>
</p>

alt="Increase" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/11px-Increase2.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/17px-Increase2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Increase2.svg/22px-Increase2.svg.png 2x" title="Increase" width="11"/> 0.925<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HDI_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-9">[8]</a></sup><br/><span class="nowrap"><span style="color:darkgreen">very high</span></span> · <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">19th</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Currency</th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/South_Korean_won" title="South Korean won">Korean Republic won</a> (₩) (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">KRW</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Time zone</th><td class="infobox-data"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Coordinated_Universal_Time" title="Coordinated Universal Time">UTC</a>+9</span> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korea_Standard_Time" title="Korea Standard Time">Korea Standard Time</a>)</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row">Date format</th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="plainlist"><ul><li>yyyy년 m월 d일</li><li>yyyy. m. d. (<a href="/wiki/Common_Era" title="Common Era">CE</a>)</li></ul></div></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Left-_and_right-hand_traffic" title="Left- and right-hand traffic">Driving side</a></th><td class="infobox-data">right</td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_South_Korea" title="Telephone numbers in South Korea">Calling code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_South_Korea" title="Telephone numbers in South Korea">+82</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166" title="ISO 3166">ISO 3166 code</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/ISO_3166-2:KR" title="ISO 3166-2:KR">KR</a></td></tr><tr><th class="infobox-label" scope="row"><a href="/wiki/Country_code_top-level_domain" title="Country code top-level domain">Internet TLD</a></th><td class="infobox-data"><div class="hlist hlist-separated"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.kr" title=".kr">.kr</a></li><li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/.%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD" title=".한국">.한국</a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>South Korea</b>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[b]</a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of Korea</b> (<b>ROK</b>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[c]</a></sup> is a <a href="/wiki/Country" title="Country">country</a> in <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, constituting the southern part of the <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korean Peninsula</a> and sharing a <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">land border</a> with <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. Its western border is formed by the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a>, while its eastern border is defined by the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a>. South Korea claims to be the sole legitimate government of the entire peninsula and <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_South_Korea" title="List of islands of South Korea">adjacent islands</a>. It has a <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_South_Korea" title="Demographics of South Korea">population</a> of 51.75 million, of which roughly half live in the <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Capital_Area" title="Seoul Capital Area">Seoul Capital Area</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_by_population" title="List of metropolitan areas by population">fifth largest metropolis in the world</a>. Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Incheon" title="Incheon">Incheon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Daegu" title="Daegu">Daegu</a>.
</p><p>The Korean Peninsula was inhabited as early as the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a> period. Its <a href="/wiki/Gojoseon" title="Gojoseon">first kingdom</a> was noted in Chinese records in the early 7th century BCE. Following the unification of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</a> into <a href="/wiki/Unified_Silla" title="Unified Silla">Silla</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balhae" title="Balhae">Balhae</a> in the late 7th century, Korea was ruled by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Goryeo_dynasty" title="Goryeo dynasty">Goryeo dynasty</a> (918–1392) and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseon_dynasty" title="Joseon dynasty">Joseon dynasty</a> (1392–1897). The succeeding <a href="/wiki/Korean_Empire" title="Korean Empire">Korean Empire</a> (1897–1910) was <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_Treaty_of_1910" title="Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910">annexed in 1910</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a>. <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japanese rule</a> ended following <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">the former's surrender</a> in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, after which Korea was <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">divided into two zones</a>; a <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Civil_Administration" title="Soviet Civil Administration">northern</a> zone occupied by the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and a <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Military_Government_in_Korea" title="United States Army Military Government in Korea">southern</a> zone <a href="/wiki/Operation_Blacklist_Forty" title="Operation Blacklist Forty">occupied</a> by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>. After negotiations on <a href="/wiki/Korean_reunification" title="Korean reunification">reunification</a> failed, the latter became the Republic of Korea in August 1948 while the former became the socialist <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" title="Democratic People's Republic of Korea">Democratic People's Republic of Korea</a> the following month.
</p><p>In 1950, a <a href="/wiki/Operation_Pokpoong" title="Operation Pokpoong">North Korean invasion</a> began the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, which saw extensive <a href="/wiki/United_States_in_the_Korean_War" title="United States in the Korean War">American</a>-led <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Command" title="United Nations Command">United Nations intervention</a> in support of the South, while <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> intervened to <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Volunteer_Army" title="People's Volunteer Army">support the North</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_in_the_Korean_War" title="Soviet Union in the Korean War">Soviet assistance</a>. After <a href="/wiki/Korean_Armistice_Agreement" title="Korean Armistice Agreement">the war's end</a> in 1953, the country entered into <a href="/wiki/Mutual_Defense_Treaty_(United_States%E2%80%93South_Korea)" title="Mutual Defense Treaty (United States–South Korea)">a military alliance with the U.S.</a>, and its devastated economy <a href="/wiki/Miracle_on_the_Han_River" title="Miracle on the Han River">began to soar</a>, recording the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_per_capita_growth_rate" title="List of countries by GDP (real) per capita growth rate">fastest rise in average GDP per capita</a> in the world between 1980 and 1990. Despite lacking natural resources, the nation rapidly developed to become one of the <a href="/wiki/Four_Asian_Tigers" title="Four Asian Tigers">Four Asian Tigers</a> based on <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">international trade</a> and <a href="/wiki/Globalization#Economic_globalization" title="Globalization">economic globalization</a>, integrating itself within the <a href="/wiki/World_economy" title="World economy">world economy</a> with <a href="/wiki/Export-oriented_industrialization" title="Export-oriented industrialization">export-oriented industrialization</a>; currently being one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">largest exporting nations</a> in the world, along with having one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_foreign-exchange_reserves" title="List of countries by foreign-exchange reserves">largest foreign-exchange reserves</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[9]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/June_Democratic_Struggle" title="June Democratic Struggle">June Democratic Struggle</a> led to the <a href="/wiki/1987_South_Korean_presidential_election" title="1987 South Korean presidential election">end of authoritarian rule in 1987</a> and the country is now considered among the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">most advanced democracies</a> in <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">Asia</a>, with the highest level of <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">press freedom</a> on the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea is a highly <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> and is ranked as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_in_Asia_and_Oceania_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries in Asia and Oceania by Human Development Index">fifth-highest country</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a> (HDI) in the Asia and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a> region. South Korea has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">third-highest life expectancy in the world</a>. In recent years, the country has been facing an <a href="/wiki/Aging_of_South_Korea" title="Aging of South Korea">aging population</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Low_birth_rate_in_South_Korea" title="Low birth rate in South Korea">lowest fertility rate</a> in the world. Its <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_Korea" title="Economy of South Korea">economy</a> ranks as the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twelfth-largest by nominal GDP</a>. Its citizens enjoy one of the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Internet_connection_speeds" title="List of countries by Internet connection speeds">fastest Internet connection speeds</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_high-speed_railway_lines" title="List of high-speed railway lines">densest high-speed railway network</a>. The country is the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">ninth-largest exporter</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">ninth-largest importer</a>. Its <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of Korea Armed Forces">armed forces</a> is ranked as one of the world's strongest militaries and is the world's second-largest standing army by <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_military_and_paramilitary_personnel" title="List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel">military and paramilitary personnel</a>. Since the 21st century, South Korea has been renowned for its globally influential pop culture, particularly in music (<a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">K-pop</a>), TV dramas (<a href="/wiki/Korean_drama" title="Korean drama">K-dramas</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_South_Korea" title="Cinema of South Korea">cinema</a>, a phenomenon referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Korean_wave" title="Korean wave">Korean wave</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup> It is a member of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Development_Assistance_Committee" title="Development Assistance Committee">Development Assistance Committee</a>, the <a href="/wiki/G20" title="G20">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Pacific_Economic_Framework" title="Indo-Pacific Economic Framework">IPEF</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Paris_Club" title="Paris Club">Paris Club</a>.
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_Korea" title="Names of Korea">Names of Korea</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:History_of_Korea-476.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1146" data-file-width="970" decoding="async" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/History_of_Korea-476.PNG/170px-History_of_Korea-476.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/History_of_Korea-476.PNG/255px-History_of_Korea-476.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/History_of_Korea-476.PNG/340px-History_of_Korea-476.PNG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:History_of_Korea-476.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The name <i>Korea</i> is derived from <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a>, also known as <i>Koryŏ</i>, one of the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The name <i>Korea</i> derives from the name <i>Goryeo</i>. The name <i>Goryeo</i> itself was first used by the ancient kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a>, which was considered a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> of East Asia during its time, in the 5th century as a shortened form of its name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18"><a href="#cite_note-18">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup> The 10th-century kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a> succeeded Goguryeo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo1_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo1-21">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo2_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo2-22">[19]</a></sup> and thus inherited its name, which was pronounced by the visiting Arab and Persian merchants as "Korea".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[20]</a></sup> The modern name of Korea, appears in the first Portuguese maps of 1568 by João vaz Dourado as <i>Conrai</i> <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[21]</a></sup> and later in the late 16th century and early 17th century as Korea (Corea) in the maps of Teixeira Albernaz of 1630.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>The kingdom of <i>Goryeo</i> became first known to Westerners when <a href="/wiki/Afonso_de_Albuquerque" title="Afonso de Albuquerque">Afonso de Albuquerque</a> conquered Malacca in 1511 and described the peoples who traded with this part of the world known by the Portuguese as the Gores.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup> Despite the coexistence of the spellings <i>Corea</i> and <i>Korea</i> in 19th century publications, some Koreans believe that <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Imperial Japan</a>, around the time of the Japanese occupation, intentionally standardized the spelling on <i>Korea</i>, making <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> appear first alphabetically.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UDN_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-UDN-27">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LATimes0309_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-LATimes0309-28">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Goryeo was replaced by Joseon in 1392, Joseon became the official name for the entire territory, though it was not universally accepted. The new official name has its origin in the ancient kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Gojoseon" title="Gojoseon">Gojoseon</a> (2333 BCE). In 1897, the <a href="/wiki/Joseon" title="Joseon">Joseon</a> dynasty changed the official name of the country from <i>Joseon</i> to <i>Daehan Jeguk</i> (<a href="/wiki/Korean_Empire" title="Korean Empire">Korean Empire</a>). The name <i>Daehan</i> (Great Han) derives from <a href="/wiki/Samhan" title="Samhan">Samhan</a> (Three Han), referring to the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</a>, not the ancient confederacies in the southern Korean Peninsula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[27]</a></sup> However, the name <i>Joseon</i> was still widely used by Koreans to refer to their country, though it was no longer the official name. Under <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japanese rule</a>, the two names <i>Han</i> and <i>Joseon</i> coexisted. There were several groups who <a href="/wiki/Korean_independence_movement" title="Korean independence movement">fought for independence</a>, the most notable being the <i><a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_the_Republic_of_Korea" title="Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea">Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea</a></i> (<span title="Korean-language text"><span lang="ko">대한민국 임시정부</span></span> / <span title="Korean-language text"><span lang="ko">大韓民國臨時政府</span></span>).
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrender of Japan</a>, in 1945, the "Republic of Korea" (<span title="Korean-language text"><span lang="ko">대한민국</span></span> / <span title="Korean-language text"><span lang="ko">大韓民國</span></span>, <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">IPA</a>: <span class="IPA" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">ˈtɛ̝ːɦa̠nminɡuk̚</span>, <abbr title="literal translation">lit.</abbr><span style="white-space: nowrap;"> </span>'Great Korean People's State'; <span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ko-Daehan_Minguk.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" decoding="async" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/></a></span><a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/45/Ko-Daehan_Minguk.ogg" title="Ko-Daehan Minguk.ogg">listen</a></span></span>) was adopted as the legal English name for the new country. However, it is not a direct translation of the Korean name.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unloved_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-unloved-31">[28]</a></sup> As a result, the Korean name "Daehan Minguk" is sometimes used by South Koreans as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metonym" title="Metonym">metonym</a> to refer to the Korean ethnicity (or "<a href="/wiki/Korean_ethnic_nationalism" title="Korean ethnic nationalism">race</a>") as a whole, rather than just the South Korean state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thefreelibrary.com_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-thefreelibrary.com-32">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unloved_31-1"><a href="#cite_note-unloved-31">[28]</a></sup> Conversely, the official name of North Korea in English, the "Democratic People's Republic of Korea", is a direct translation of the Korean name.
</p><p>Since the government only controlled the southern part of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, the informal term "South Korea" was coined, becoming increasingly common in the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western world</a>. While South Koreans use <i>Han</i> (or <i>Hanguk</i>) to refer to both Koreas collectively, North Koreans and ethnic Koreans living in China and Japan use the term <i>Joseon</i> instead.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Korea" title="History of Korea">History of Korea</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ancient_Korea">Ancient Korea</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner"
