class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif"><img alt="" data-file-height="1198" data-file-width="1014" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif/200px-History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif/300px-History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif/400px-History_of_Korea-Inter-country_Age-830_CE.gif 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Balhae" title="Balhae">Balhae</a> (violet) and <a href="/wiki/Unified_Silla" title="Unified Silla">Silla</a> (blue), circa 830 CE</div></div></div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg/200px-Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg/300px-Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg/400px-Korean_book-Jikji-Selected_Teachings_of_Buddhist_Sages_and_Seon_Masters-1377.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The oldest surviving metal movable type book, the <a href="/wiki/Jikji" title="Jikji">Jikji</a>, was printed in 1377, and <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a> created the world's first metal-based movable type in 1234.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-print_c_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-print_c-33">[30]</a></sup></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/200px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/300px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg/400px-Korea-Haeinsa-Tripitaka_Koreana-01.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <i><a href="/wiki/Tripitaka_Koreana" title="Tripitaka Koreana">Tripitaka Koreana</a></i> — the Buddhist canon (<i><a href="/wiki/Tripi%E1%B9%ADaka" title="Tripiṭaka">Tripiṭaka</a></i>) carved onto roughly 80,000 woodblocks and stored (and still remaining) at <a href="/wiki/Haeinsa" title="Haeinsa">Haeinsa</a>, also a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Korean Peninsula was inhabited as early as the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Paleolithic" title="Lower Paleolithic">Lower Paleolithic</a> period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/History_of_Korea" title="History of Korea">history of Korea</a> begins with the founding of Joseon (also known as "<a href="/wiki/Gojoseon" title="Gojoseon">Gojoseon</a>", or Old Joseon, to differentiate it with the 14th century dynasty) in 2333 BCE by <a href="/wiki/Dangun" title="Dangun">Dangun</a>, according to Korea's <a href="/wiki/Civil_religion" title="Civil religion">foundation mythology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-koreashistory_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-koreashistory-36">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DangunGija_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-DangunGija-37">[34]</a></sup> Gojoseon was noted in Chinese records in the early 7th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup> Gojoseon expanded until it controlled the northern Korean Peninsula and parts of <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">Manchuria</a>. <a href="/wiki/Gija_Joseon" title="Gija Joseon">Gija Joseon</a> was purportedly founded in the 12th century BCE, but its existence and role have been controversial in the modern era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DangunGija_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-DangunGija-37">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup> In 108 BCE, the <a href="/wiki/Han_dynasty" title="Han dynasty">Han dynasty</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gojoseon%E2%80%93Han_War" title="Gojoseon–Han War">defeated</a> <a href="/wiki/Wiman_Joseon" title="Wiman Joseon">Wiman Joseon</a> and installed <a href="/wiki/Four_Commanderies_of_Han" title="Four Commanderies of Han">four commanderies</a> in the northern Korean peninsula. Three of the commanderies fell or retreated westward within a few decades. As <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lelang_commandery" title="Lelang commandery">Lelang commandery</a> was destroyed and rebuilt around this time, the place gradually moved toward Liaodong. Thus, its force was diminished and it only served as a trade center until it was conquered by <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a> in 313.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gojoseon_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gojoseon-40">[37]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</span></h3>
<p>During the period known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Proto%E2%80%93Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Proto–Three Kingdoms of Korea">Proto–Three Kingdoms of Korea</a>, the states of <a href="/wiki/Buyeo" title="Buyeo">Buyeo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Okjeo" title="Okjeo">Okjeo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Ye" title="Eastern Ye">Dongye</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samhan" title="Samhan">Samhan</a> occupied the whole <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_peninsula" title="Korean peninsula">Korean peninsula</a> and <a href="/wiki/Manchuria" title="Manchuria">southern Manchuria</a>. From them, <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baekje" title="Baekje">Baekje</a> and <a href="/wiki/Silla" title="Silla">Silla</a> emerged to control the peninsula as the <a href="/wiki/Three_Kingdoms_of_Korea" title="Three Kingdoms of Korea">Three Kingdoms of Korea</a>. Goguryeo, the largest and most powerful among them, was a highly militaristic state,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[41]</a></sup> and competed with various Chinese dynasties during its 700 years of history. Goguryeo experienced a golden age under <a href="/wiki/Gwanggaeto_the_Great" title="Gwanggaeto the Great">Gwanggaeto the Great</a> and his son <a href="/wiki/Jangsu_of_Goguryeo" title="Jangsu of Goguryeo">Jangsu</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[44]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[45]</a></sup> who both subdued Baekje and Silla during their times, achieving a brief unification of the Three Kingdoms of Korea and becoming the most dominant power on the Korean Peninsula.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jinwung_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jinwung-49">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[47]</a></sup> In addition to contesting for control of the Korean Peninsula, Goguryeo had many <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Goguryeo" title="Military history of Goguryeo">military conflicts</a> with various Chinese dynasties,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[48]</a></sup> most notably the <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo%E2%80%93Sui_War" title="Goguryeo–Sui War">Goguryeo–Sui War</a>, in which Goguryeo defeated a huge force said to number over a million men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[49]</a></sup> Baekje was a great maritime power;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[50]</a></sup> its nautical skill, which made it the <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicia</a> of East Asia, was instrumental in the dissemination of Buddhism throughout East Asia and continental culture to Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[51]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> Baekje was once a great military power on the Korean Peninsula, especially during the time of <a href="/wiki/Geunchogo_of_Baekje" title="Geunchogo of Baekje">Geunchogo</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[53]</a></sup> but was critically defeated by Gwanggaeto the Great and declined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[54]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Self-published_sources" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on a self-published source. (December 2017)">self-published source</span></a></i>]</sup> Silla was the smallest and weakest of the three, but it used cunning diplomatic means to make opportunistic pacts and alliances with the more powerful Korean kingdoms, and eventually <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang China</a>, to its great advantage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>The unification of the Three Kingdoms by Silla in 676 led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_South_States_Period" title="North South States Period">North South States Period</a>, in which much of the Korean Peninsula was controlled by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Later_Silla" title="Later Silla">Later Silla</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Balhae" title="Balhae">Balhae</a> controlled the northern parts of Goguryeo. Balhae was founded by a <a href="/wiki/Go_of_Balhae" title="Go of Balhae">Goguryeo general</a> and formed as a successor state to Goguryeo. During its height, Balhae controlled most of Manchuria and parts of the Russian Far East, and was called the "Prosperous Country in the East".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[57]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Later_Silla" title="Later Silla">Later Silla</a> was a golden age of art and culture,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[61]</a></sup> as evidenced by the <a href="/wiki/Hwangnyongsa" title="Hwangnyongsa">Hwangnyongsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seokguram" title="Seokguram">Seokguram</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emille_Bell" title="Emille Bell">Emille Bell</a>. Relationships between Korea and China remained relatively peaceful during this time. Later Silla carried on the maritime prowess of <a href="/wiki/Baekje" title="Baekje">Baekje</a>, which acted like the <a href="/wiki/Phoenicia" title="Phoenicia">Phoenicia</a> of medieval <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[62]</a></sup> and during the 8th and 9th centuries dominated the seas of East Asia and the trade between China, Korea and Japan, most notably during the time of <a href="/wiki/Jang_Bogo" title="Jang Bogo">Jang Bogo</a>; in addition, Silla people made overseas communities in China on the <a href="/wiki/Shandong_Peninsula" title="Shandong Peninsula">Shandong Peninsula</a> and the mouth of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yangtze_River" title="Yangtze River">Yangtze River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[65]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[66]</a></sup> Later Silla was a prosperous and wealthy country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[67]</a></sup> and its metropolitan capital of <a href="/wiki/Gyeongju" title="Gyeongju">Gyeongju</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup> was the fourth largest city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[72]</a></sup> Buddhism flourished during this time, and many Korean Buddhists gained great fame among Chinese Buddhists<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[73]</a></sup> and contributed to Chinese Buddhism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup> including: <a href="/wiki/Woncheuk" title="Woncheuk">Woncheuk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wonhyo" title="Wonhyo">Wonhyo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uisang" title="Uisang">Uisang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Hwasang" title="Kim Hwasang">Musang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[77]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[78]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kim_Gyo-gak" title="Kim Gyo-gak">Kim Gyo-gak</a>, a Silla prince whose influence made <a href="/wiki/Mount_Jiuhua" title="Mount Jiuhua">Mount Jiuhua</a> one of the Four <a href="/wiki/Sacred_Mountains_of_China" title="Sacred Mountains of China">Sacred Mountains</a> of Chinese Buddhism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup> However, Later Silla weakened under internal strife and the revival of <a href="/wiki/Later_Baekje" title="Later Baekje">Baekje</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taebong" title="Taebong">Goguryeo</a>, which led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Later_Three_Kingdoms_period" title="Later Three Kingdoms period">Later Three Kingdoms period</a> in the late 9th century.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Unified_dynasties">Unified dynasties</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_(2014)_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="822" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="87" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_%282014%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%EC%B0%BD%EB%8D%95%EA%B6%81_%EC%A0%84%EA%B2%BD_(2014)_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Changdeokgung" title="Changdeokgung">Changdeok Palace</a>, one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Five_Grand_Palaces" title="Five Grand Palaces">Five Grand Palaces</a> built during the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Joseon_Dynasty" title="Joseon Dynasty">Joseon Dynasty</a> and another <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Site" title="UNESCO World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 936, the Later Three Kingdoms were united by <a href="/wiki/Taejo_of_Goryeo" title="Taejo of Goryeo">Wang Geon</a>, a descendant of Goguryeo nobility,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[80]</a></sup> who established <a href="/wiki/Goryeo" title="Goryeo">Goryeo</a> as the successor state of <a href="/wiki/Goguryeo" title="Goguryeo">Goguryeo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo1_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo1-21">[18]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo2_22-1"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo2-22">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo3_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo3-84">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koryo4_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koryo4-85">[82]</a></sup> Balhae had fallen to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Khitan_Empire" title="Khitan Empire">Khitan Empire</a> in 926, and a decade later the <a href="/wiki/Dae_Gwang-hyeon" title="Dae Gwang-hyeon">last crown prince of Balhae</a> fled south to Goryeo, where he was warmly welcomed and included into the ruling family by Wang Geon, thus unifying the two successor nations of Goguryeo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup> Like Silla, Goryeo was a highly cultural state, and invented the metal movable type <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">printing press</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-print_c_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-print_c-33">[30]</a></sup> After defeating the Khitan Empire, which was the most powerful empire of its time,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[84]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[85]</a></sup> in the <a href="/wiki/Goryeo%E2%80%93Khitan_War" title="Goryeo–Khitan War">Goryeo–Khitan War</a>, Goryeo experienced a golden age that lasted a century, during which the <a href="/wiki/Tripitaka_Koreana" title="Tripitaka Koreana">Tripitaka Koreana</a> was completed and there were great developments in printing and publishing, promoting learning and dispersing knowledge on philosophy, literature, religion, and science; by 1100, there were 12 universities that produced famous scholars and scientists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> However, the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasions_of_Korea" title="Mongol invasions of Korea">Mongol invasions</a> in the 13th century greatly weakened the kingdom. Goryeo was never conquered by the Mongols, but exhausted after three decades of fighting, the Korean court sent its <a href="/wiki/Wonjong_of_Goryeo" title="Wonjong of Goryeo">crown prince</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Yuan_dynasty" title="Yuan dynasty">Yuan</a> capital to swear allegiance to <a href="/wiki/Kublai_Khan" title="Kublai Khan">Kublai Khan</a>, who accepted, and married one of his daughters to the Korean crown prince.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mongols_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mongols-91">[88]</a></sup> Henceforth, Goryeo continued to rule Korea, though as a tributary ally to the Mongols for the next 86 years. During this period, the two nations became intertwined as all subsequent Korean kings married Mongol princesses,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mongols_91-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mongols-91">[88]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Empress_Gi" title="Empress Gi">last empress</a> of the Yuan dynasty was a Korean princess. In the mid-14th century, Goryeo drove out the Mongols to regain its northern territories, briefly conquered <a href="/wiki/Liaoyang" title="Liaoyang">Liaoyang</a>, and defeated invasions by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Turbans_invasions_of_Goryeo" title="Red Turbans invasions of Goryeo">Red Turbans</a>. However, in 1392, General <a href="/wiki/Taejo_of_Joseon" title="Taejo of Joseon">Yi Seong-gye</a>, who had been ordered to attack China, turned his army around and staged a coup.
</p><p>Yi Seong-gye declared the new name of Korea as "Joseon" in reference to Gojoseon, and moved the capital to Hanseong (one of the old names of <a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup> The first 200 years of the Joseon dynasty were marked by peace, and saw great advancements in science<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[91]</a></sup> and education,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[92]</a></sup> as well as the creation of <a href="/wiki/Hangul" title="Hangul">Hangul</a> by <a href="/wiki/Sejong_the_Great" title="Sejong the Great">Sejong the Great</a> to promote literacy among the common people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hangul_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hangul-96">[93]</a></sup> The prevailing ideology of the time was <a href="/wiki/Korean_Confucianism" title="Korean Confucianism">Neo-Confucianism</a>, which was epitomized by the <a href="/wiki/Seonbi" title="Seonbi">seonbi</a> class: nobles who passed up positions of wealth and power to lead lives of study and integrity. Between 1592 and 1598, <a href="/wiki/Toyotomi_Hideyoshi" title="Toyotomi Hideyoshi">Toyotomi Hideyoshi</a> launched <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japanese_invasions_of_Korea" title="Japanese invasions of Korea">invasions of Korea</a>, but his advance was halted by Korean forces (most notably the <a href="/wiki/Joseon_Navy" title="Joseon Navy">Joseon Navy</a> led by Admiral <a href="/wiki/Yi_Sun-sin" title="Yi Sun-sin">Yi Sun-sin</a> and his renowned "<a href="/wiki/Turtle_ship" title="Turtle ship">turtle ship</a>") with assistance from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Righteous_Army" title="Righteous Army">Righteous Army</a> militias formed by Korean civilians, and <a href="/wiki/Ming_dynasty" title="Ming dynasty">Ming dynasty</a> Chinese troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Perez_2013_140–141_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-Perez_2013_140–141-97">[94]</a></sup> Through a series of successful battles of attrition, the Japanese forces were eventually forced to withdraw, and relations between all parties became normalized. However, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manchus" title="Manchus">Manchus</a> took advantage of Joseon's war-weakened state and <a href="/wiki/Manchu_invasion_of_Korea" title="Manchu invasion of Korea">invaded</a> in 1627 and 1637, and then went on to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Qing_conquest_of_the_Ming" title="Qing conquest of the Ming">conquer</a> the destabilized Ming dynasty. After normalizing relations with the new <a href="/wiki/Qing_dynasty" title="Qing dynasty">Qing dynasty</a>, Joseon experienced a nearly 200-year period of peace. Kings <a href="/wiki/Yeongjo_of_Joseon" title="Yeongjo of Joseon">Yeongjo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jeongjo_of_Joseon" title="Jeongjo of Joseon">Jeongjo</a> particularly led a new renaissance of the Joseon dynasty during the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[96]</a></sup> In the 19th century, the royal in-law families gained control of the government, leading to mass corruption and weakening of the state, and severe poverty and peasant rebellions throughout the country. Furthermore, the Joseon government adopted a strict isolationist policy, earning the nickname "the <a href="/wiki/Hermit_kingdom" title="Hermit kingdom">hermit kingdom</a>", but ultimately failed to protect itself against <a href="/wiki/Imperialism" title="Imperialism">imperialism</a> and was forced to open its borders. After the <a href="/wiki/First_Sino-Japanese_War" title="First Sino-Japanese War">First Sino-Japanese War</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a>, Korea was <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">annexed by Japan</a> (1910–1945). What followed was a period of forced assimilation, in which Korean language, culture, and history were suppressed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100"><a href="#cite_note-100">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Towards the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the U.S. proposed dividing the Korean peninsula into two occupation zones (a U.S. and Soviet one). <a href="/wiki/Dean_Rusk" title="Dean Rusk">Dean Rusk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charles_H._Bonesteel_III" title="Charles H. Bonesteel III">Charles H. Bonesteel III</a> suggested the <a href="/wiki/38th_parallel_north" title="38th parallel north">38th parallel</a> as the dividing line, as it placed Seoul under U.S. control. To the surprise of Rusk and Bonesteel, the Soviets accepted their proposal and agreed to divide Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_South_Korea" title="History of South Korea">History of South Korea</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2479" data-file-width="3703" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG/220px-War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG/330px-War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG/440px-War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:War_Memorial_of_Korea_main_building.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/War_Memorial_of_Korea" title="War Memorial of Korea">War Memorial of Korea</a>, built in remembrance of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> (1950–1953)</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_Korea%27s_GDP_(PPP)_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="929" data-file-width="1508" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png/220px-South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png/330px-South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png/440px-South_Korea%27s_GDP_%28PPP%29_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:South_Korea%27s_GDP_(PPP)_growth_from_1911_to_2008.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Between 1962 and 1994, the <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_Korea" title="Economy of South Korea">South Korean economy</a> grew at an average of 10% annually, fueled by annual export growth of 20%,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-worldbank.org_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank.org-102">[99]</a></sup> in a period called the <a href="/wiki/Miracle_on_the_Han_River" title="Miracle on the Han River">Miracle on the Han River</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Despite the initial plan of a <a href="/wiki/Korean_reunification" title="Korean reunification">unified Korea</a> in the <a href="/wiki/1943_Cairo_Declaration" title="1943 Cairo Declaration">1943 Cairo Declaration</a>, escalating <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a> antagonism between the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> eventually led to the establishment of separate governments, each with its own ideology, leading to the <a href="/wiki/Division_of_Korea" title="Division of Korea">division of Korea</a> into two political entities in 1948: <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> and South Korea. In the South, <a href="/wiki/Syngman_Rhee" title="Syngman Rhee">Syngman Rhee</a>, an opponent of communism, who had been backed and appointed by the United States as head of the provisional government, won the first presidential elections of the newly declared Republic of Korea in May. In the North, however, a former anti-Japanese guerrilla and communist activist, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Il-sung" title="Kim Il-sung">Kim Il-sung</a>, was appointed premier of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea in September.
</p><p>In October, the Soviet Union declared Kim Il-sung's government as sovereign over both parts. The UN declared Rhee's government as "a lawful government having effective control and jurisdiction over that part of Korea where the UN Temporary Commission on Korea was able to observe and consult" and the Government "based on elections which was observed by the Temporary Commission" in addition to a statement that "this is the only such government in Korea."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN195_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN195-103">[100]</a></sup> Both leaders began an authoritarian repression of their political opponents inside their region, seeking for a unification of Korea under their control.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[101]</a></sup> While South Korea's request for military support was denied by the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[102]</a></sup> North Korea's military was heavily reinforced by the Soviet Union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Korean_War">Korean War</span></h4>
<p>On 25 June 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea, sparking the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, the Cold War's first major conflict, which continued until 1953. At the time, the Soviet Union had boycotted the United Nations (UN), thus forfeiting their veto rights. This allowed the UN to intervene in a civil war when it became apparent that the superior North Korean forces would unify the entire country. The Soviet Union and China backed North Korea, with the later participation of millions of <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Volunteer_Army" title="People's Volunteer Army">Chinese troops</a>. After an ebb and flow that saw both sides facing defeat with massive losses among Korean civilians in both the north and the south, the war eventually reached a stalemate. During the war, Rhee's party promoted the <a href="/wiki/Ilminism" title="Ilminism">One-People Principle</a> (based on the German <a href="/wiki/Ideology" title="Ideology">ideology</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Master_race" title="Master race">Herrenvolk</a></i>) an effort to build an obedient citizenry through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnicity" title="Ethnicity">ethnic</a> homogeneity and authoritarian appeals to <a href="/wiki/Nationalism" title="Nationalism">nationalism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hwang93_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hwang93-108">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1953 armistice, never signed by South Korea, split the peninsula along the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">demilitarized zone</a> near the original demarcation line. No peace treaty was ever signed, resulting in the two countries remaining technically at war. Approximately 3 million people died in the Korean War, with a higher proportional civilian death toll than <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> or the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, making it one of the deadliest conflicts of the Cold War era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kim_p.45_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kim_p.45-109">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cumings_p._35_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cumings_p._35-110">[107]</a></sup> In addition, virtually all of Korea's major cities were destroyed by the war.&gt;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewy_pp._450-453_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewy_pp._450-453-111">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Post-Korean_War_.281960.E2.80.931990.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Korean_War_(1960–1990)">Post-Korean War (1960–1990)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="436" decoding="async" height="234" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png/170px-Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png/255px-Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png/340px-Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Park_Chung-hee_1963%27s.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Park_Chung-hee" title="Park Chung-hee">Park Chung-hee</a> played a pivotal role in rapidly developing South Korea's economy through <a href="/wiki/Export-oriented_industrialization" title="Export-oriented industrialization">export-oriented industrialization</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1960, <a href="/wiki/April_Revolution" title="April Revolution">a student uprising</a> (the "April 19 Revolution") led to the resignation of the autocratic <a href="/wiki/Syngman_Rhee" title="Syngman Rhee">then-President Syngman Rhee</a>. This was followed by 13 months of political instability as South Korea was led by a weak and ineffectual government. This instability was broken by the <a href="/wiki/May_16_coup" title="May 16 coup">16 May 1961, coup</a> led by General <a href="/wiki/Park_Chung-hee" title="Park Chung-hee">Park Chung-hee</a>. As president, Park oversaw a period of rapid <a href="/wiki/Export-oriented_industrialization" title="Export-oriented industrialization">export-led economic growth</a> enforced by political repression.
</p><p>Park was heavily criticized as a ruthless military dictator, who in 1972 extended his rule by creating a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yusin_Constitution" title="Yusin Constitution">new constitution</a>, which gave the president sweeping (almost dictatorial) powers and permitted him to run for an unlimited number of six-year terms. The <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_Korea" title="Economy of South Korea">Korean economy</a> developed significantly during Park's tenure.  The government developed the <a href="/wiki/Expressways_in_South_Korea" title="Expressways in South Korea">nationwide expressway system</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Metropolitan_Subway" title="Seoul Metropolitan Subway">Seoul subway system</a>, and laid the foundation for economic development during his 17-year tenure, which ended with <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Park_Chung-hee" title="Assassination of Park Chung-hee">his assassination</a> in 1979.
</p><p>The years after Park's assassination were marked again by political turmoil, as the previously suppressed opposition leaders all campaigned to run for president in the sudden political void. In 1979, General <a href="/wiki/Chun_Doo-hwan" title="Chun Doo-hwan">Chun Doo-hwan</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_of_December_Twelfth" title="Coup d'état of December Twelfth">coup d'état of December Twelfth</a>. Following the coup d'état, Chun Doo-hwan planned to rise to power through several measures. On 17 May, Chun Doo-hwan forced the Cabinet to expand martial law to the whole nation, which had previously not applied to the island of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jejudo" title="Jejudo">Jejudo</a>. The expanded martial law closed universities, banned political activities, and further curtailed the press. Chun's assumption of the presidency through the events of 17 May triggered nationwide protests demanding democracy; these protests were particularly focused in the city of <a href="/wiki/Gwangju" title="Gwangju">Gwangju</a>, to which Chun sent special forces to violently suppress the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gwangju_massacre" title="Gwangju massacre">Gwangju Democratization Movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Chun subsequently created the National Defense Emergency Policy Committee and took the presidency according to his political plan. Chun and his government held South Korea under a despotic rule until 1987, when a <a href="/wiki/Seoul_National_University" title="Seoul National University">Seoul National University</a> student, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bak_Jongcheol" title="Bak Jongcheol">Park Jong-chul</a>, was tortured to death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[110]</a></sup> On <span class="nowrap">10 June</span>, the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Priests_Association_for_Justice" title="Catholic Priests Association for Justice">Catholic Priests Association for Justice</a> revealed the incident, igniting the <a href="/wiki/June_Democratic_Struggle" title="June Democratic Struggle">June Democratic Struggle</a> across the country. Eventually, Chun's party, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Justice_Party" title="Democratic Justice Party">Democratic Justice Party</a>, and its leader, <a href="/wiki/Roh_Tae-woo" title="Roh Tae-woo">Roh Tae-woo</a>, announced the 6.29 Declaration, which included the direct election of the president. Roh went on to win the election by a narrow margin against the two main opposition leaders, <a href="/wiki/Kim_Dae-jung" title="Kim Dae-jung">Kim Dae-jung</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kim_Young-sam" title="Kim Young-sam">Kim Young-sam</a>. Seoul hosted the <a href="/wiki/1988_Summer_Olympics" title="1988 Summer Olympics">Olympic Games in 1988</a>, widely regarded as successful and a significant boost for South Korea's global image and economy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_702" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 702">South Korea was formally invited</a> to become a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> in 1991. The transition of Korea from autocracy to modern democracy was marked in 1997 by the election of Kim Dae-jung, who was sworn in as the eighth president of South Korea, on 25 February 1998. His election was significant given that he had in earlier years been a political prisoner sentenced to death (later commuted to exile). He won against the backdrop of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1997_Asian_Financial_Crisis" title="1997 Asian Financial Crisis">1997 Asian Financial Crisis</a>, where he took <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">IMF</a> advice to restructure the economy and the nation soon recovered its economic growth, albeit at a slower pace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-115">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_South_Korea">Contemporary South Korea</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6000" data-file-width="5000" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg/170px-Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg/255px-Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg/340px-Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kim_Dae-jung_presidential_portrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Kim_Dae-jung" title="Kim Dae-jung">Kim Dae-jung</a>, the 2000 <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> recipient for advancing democracy and human rights in South Korea and East Asia and for reconciliation with North Korea, was sometimes called the "<a href="/wiki/Nelson_Mandela" title="Nelson Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a> of Asia."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto1_115-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-115">[112]</a></sup></div></div></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}html.client-js body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="Ambox current red Asia Australia.svg" data-file-height="290" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" width="42"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">September 2022</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>In June 2000, as part of president Kim Dae-jung's "<a href="/wiki/Sunshine_Policy" title="Sunshine Policy">Sunshine Policy</a>" of engagement, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Inter-Korean_summit" title="Inter-Korean summit">North–South summit</a> took place in <a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a>, the capital of North Korea. Later that year, Kim received the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> "for his work for democracy and human rights in South Korea and in East Asia in general, and for peace and reconciliation with North Korea in particular".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[113]</a></sup> However, because of discontent among the population for fruitless approaches to the North under the previous administrations and, amid North Korean provocations, a conservative government was elected in 2007 led by President <a href="/wiki/Lee_Myung-bak" title="Lee Myung-bak">Lee Myung-bak</a>, former <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_Seoul" title="Mayor of Seoul">mayor of Seoul</a>. Meanwhile, South Korea and Japan jointly co-hosted the <a href="/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2002 FIFA World Cup">2002 FIFA World Cup</a>. However, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_relations" title="Japan–Korea relations">South Korean and Japanese relations</a> later <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_disputes" title="Japan–Korea disputes">soured</a> because of conflicting claims of <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> over the <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks_dispute" title="Liancourt Rocks dispute">Liancourt Rocks</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1394" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg/220px-2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg/330px-2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg/440px-2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2010_G-20_Seoul_summit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>South Korea became the first non-<a href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">G7</a> chair of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20" title="G-20">G-20</a> when it hosted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2010_G-20_Seoul_summit" title="2010 G-20 Seoul summit">2010 Seoul summit</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[114]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In 2010, there was an <a href="/wiki/List_of_border_incidents_involving_North_and_South_Korea" title="List of border incidents involving North and South Korea">escalation in attacks</a> by North Korea. In March 2010 the South Korean warship <a href="/wiki/ROKS_Cheonan_sinking" title="ROKS Cheonan sinking">ROKS Cheonan</a> was sunk leading to the death of 46 South Korean sailors, allegedly by a North Korean submarine. In November 2010 <a href="/wiki/Bombardment_of_Yeonpyeong" title="Bombardment of Yeonpyeong">Yeonpyeong</a> island was attacked by a significant North Korean artillery barrage, with 4 people dying. The lack of a strong response to these attacks from both South Korea and the international community (the official UN report declined to explicitly name North Korea as the perpetrator for the <a href="/wiki/Cheonan" title="Cheonan">Cheonan</a> sinking) caused significant anger with the South Korean public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea saw another milestone in 2012 with the first ever female president <a href="/wiki/Park_Geun-hye" title="Park Geun-hye">Park Geun-hye</a> <a href="/wiki/2012_South_Korean_presidential_election" title="2012 South Korean presidential election">elected</a> and assuming office. Daughter of another former president, <a href="/wiki/Park_Chung-hee" title="Park Chung-hee">Park Chung-hee</a>, she carried on a conservative brand of politics. President Park Geun-hye's administration was formally accused of corruption, bribery, and influence-peddling for the involvement of close friend <a href="/wiki/Choi_Soon-sil" title="Choi Soon-sil">Choi Soon-sil</a> in state affairs. There followed a series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_South_Korean_protests" title="2016–17 South Korean protests">massive public demonstrations</a> from November 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[116]</a></sup> and she was removed from office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[117]</a></sup> After the fallout of President Park's impeachment and dismissal, new elections were held and <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> of the Democratic party won the presidency, assuming office on 10 May 2017. His tenure saw an improving political relationship with North Korea, some increasing divergence in the military alliance with the United States, and the successful hosting of <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[118]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_Korea" title="COVID-19 pandemic in South Korea">The COVID-19 pandemic</a> has affected the nation since 2020. That same year, South Korea recorded more deaths than births, resulting in a population decline for the first time on record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[119]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2022, <a href="/wiki/Yoon_Suk-yeol" title="Yoon Suk-yeol">Yoon Suk-yeol</a>, the candidate of conservative opposition <a href="/wiki/People_Power_Party_(South_Korea)" title="People Power Party (South Korea)">People Power Party</a>, won a close <a href="/wiki/2022_South_Korean_presidential_election" title="2022 South Korean presidential election">election</a> over <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_of_Korea" title="Democratic Party of Korea">Democratic Party</a> candidate by the narrowest margin ever. On 10 May 2022, Yoon Suk-yeol was sworn in as South Korea's new president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Geography.2C_climate_and_environment"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography,_climate_and_environment">Geography, climate and environment</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_South_Korea" title="Geography of South Korea">Geography of South Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geology_of_South_Korea" title="Geology of South Korea">Geology of South Korea</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_Korea_Topography.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1979" data-file-width="1705" decoding="async" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/South_Korea_Topography.png/220px-South_Korea_Topography.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/South_Korea_Topography.png/330px-South_Korea_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/South_Korea_Topography.png/440px-South_Korea_Topography.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:South_Korea_Topography.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">Topography</a> of South Korea</div></div></div>
<p>South Korea occupies the southern portion of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_Peninsula" title="Korean Peninsula">Korean Peninsula</a>, which extends some 1,100 km (680 mi) from the Asian mainland. This mountainous peninsula is flanked by the <a href="/wiki/Yellow_Sea" title="Yellow Sea">Yellow Sea</a> to the west, and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a> to the east. Its southern tip lies on the <a href="/wiki/Korea_Strait" title="Korea Strait">Korea Strait</a> and the <a href="/wiki/East_China_Sea" title="East China Sea">East China Sea</a>.
</p><p>The country, including all its islands, lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/33rd_parallel_north" title="33rd parallel north">33°</a> and <a href="/wiki/39th_parallel_north" title="39th parallel north">39°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/124th_meridian_east" title="124th meridian east">124°</a> and <a href="/wiki/130th_meridian_east" title="130th meridian east">130°E</a>. Its total area is 100,032 square kilometers (38,622.57 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea can be divided into four general regions: an eastern region of high mountain ranges and narrow <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coastal_plains" title="Coastal plains">coastal plains</a>; a western region of broad coastal plains, <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">river basins</a>, and rolling hills; a southwestern region of mountains and valleys; and a southeastern region dominated by the broad basin of the <a href="/wiki/Nakdong_River" title="Nakdong River">Nakdong River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-korea_geo_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-korea_geo-125">[122]</a></sup> South Korea is home to three terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Central_Korean_deciduous_forests" title="Central Korean deciduous forests">Central Korean deciduous forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manchurian_mixed_forests" title="Manchurian mixed forests">Manchurian mixed forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Korea_evergreen_forests" title="Southern Korea evergreen forests">Southern Korea evergreen forests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-126">[123]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea's terrain is mostly mountainous, most of which is not <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lowland" title="Lowland">Lowlands</a>, located primarily in the west and southeast, make up only 30% of the total land area.
</p><p>About three thousand islands, mostly small and uninhabited, lie off the western and southern coasts of South Korea. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jeju-do" title="Jeju-do">Jeju-do</a> is about 100 kilometers (62 miles) off the southern coast of South Korea. It is the country's largest island, with an area of 1,845 square kilometers (712 square miles). Jeju is also the site of South Korea's highest point: <a href="/wiki/Hallasan" title="Hallasan">Hallasan</a>, an extinct <a href="/wiki/Volcano" title="Volcano">volcano</a>, reaches 1,950 meters (6,400 feet) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>. The easternmost islands of South Korea include <a href="/wiki/Ulleungdo" title="Ulleungdo">Ulleungdo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks" title="Liancourt Rocks">Liancourt Rocks</a> (Dokdo/Takeshima), while <a href="/wiki/Marado" title="Marado">Marado</a> and <a href="/wiki/Socotra_Rock" title="Socotra Rock">Socotra Rock</a> are the southernmost islands of South Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-korea_geo_125-1"><a href="#cite_note-korea_geo-125">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea has <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_parks_of_South_Korea" title="National parks of South Korea">20 national parks</a> and popular nature places like the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boseong" title="Boseong">Boseong</a> Tea Fields, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suncheon_Ecological_Park" title="Suncheon Ecological Park">Suncheon Bay Ecological Park</a>, and the first national park of <a href="/wiki/Jirisan" title="Jirisan">Jirisan</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Climate_of_South_Korea" title="Climate of South Korea">Climate of South Korea</a></div>
<table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" class="infobox" style="width: 19.5em; float: right; clear: right; text-align: center; border: solid 1px silver">
