Political figures such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kim_Koo" title="Kim Koo">Kim Koo</a> worked to reconcile the two governments even after the Korean War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[222]</a></sup> With longstanding animosity following the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> from 1950 to 1953, North Korea and South Korea signed an agreement to pursue peace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-226">[223]</a></sup> On 4 October 2007, Roh Moo-Hyun and North Korean leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-il" title="Kim Jong-il">Kim Jong-il</a> signed an eight-point agreement on issues of permanent peace, high-level talks, economic cooperation, renewal of train services, highway and air travel, and a joint Olympic cheering squad.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_226-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-226">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="943" data-file-width="1415" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/220px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/330px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg/440px-2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2018_inter-Korean_summit_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>North Korean leader <a href="/wiki/Kim_Jong-un" title="Kim Jong-un">Kim Jong-un</a> and South Korean President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> shake hands inside the <a href="/wiki/Inter-Korean_Peace_House" title="Inter-Korean Peace House">Peace House</a></div></div></div>
<p>Despite the Sunshine Policy and efforts at reconciliation, the progress was complicated by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Korean_missile_tests" title="North Korean missile tests">North Korean missile tests</a> in <a href="/wiki/1993_North_Korean_missile_test" title="1993 North Korean missile test">1993</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1998_North_Korean_missile_test" title="1998 North Korean missile test">1998</a>, <a href="/wiki/2006_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2006 North Korean nuclear test">2006</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_North_Korean_nuclear_test" title="2009 North Korean nuclear test">2009</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2013_North_Korean_missile_tests" title="2013 North Korean missile tests">2013</a>. By early 2009, relationships between North and South Korea were very tense; North Korea had been reported to have deployed missiles,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[224]</a></sup> ended its former agreements with South Korea,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[225]</a></sup> and threatened South Korea and the United States not to interfere with a satellite launch it had planned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[226]</a></sup> North and South Korea are still technically at war (having never signed a peace treaty after the Korean War) and share the world's most heavily fortified border.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-border_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-border-230">[227]</a></sup> On 27 May 2009, North Korean media declared that the Armistice is no longer valid because of the South Korean government's pledge to "definitely join" the <a href="/wiki/Proliferation_Security_Initiative" title="Proliferation Security Initiative">Proliferation Security Initiative</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[228]</a></sup> To further complicate and intensify strains between the two nations, the <a href="/wiki/ROKS_Cheonan_sinking" title="ROKS Cheonan sinking">sinking of the South Korean warship Cheonan</a> in March 2010 was affirmed by the South Korean government<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[229]</a></sup> to have been caused by a North Korean torpedo, which the North denies. President <a href="/wiki/Lee_Myung-bak" title="Lee Myung-bak">Lee Myung-bak</a> declared in May 2010 that Seoul would cut all trade with North Korea as part of measures primarily aimed at striking back at North Korea diplomatically and financially, except for the joint Kaesong Industrial Project and humanitarian aid.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kaesong_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-kaesong-233">[230]</a></sup> North Korea initially threatened to sever all ties, to completely abrogate the previous pact of non-aggression, and to expel all South Koreans from <a href="/wiki/Kaesong_Industrial_Region" title="Kaesong Industrial Region">a joint industrial zone in Kaesong</a>, but backtracked on its threats and decided to continue its ties with South Korea. Despite the continuing ties, the Kaesong Industrial Region has seen a large decrease in investment and manpower as a result of this military conflict. In February 2016, the Kaesong complex was closed by Seoul in reaction to North Korea's launch of a rocket earlier in the month,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[231]</a></sup> which was unanimously condemned by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[232]</a></sup>
The 2017 election of President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> has seen a change in approach towards the North, and both sides used the South Korean-held <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">2018 Winter Olympics</a> as an opportunity for engagement,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[233]</a></sup> with a very senior North Korean political delegation sent to the games, along with a reciprocal visit by senior South Korean cabinet members to the North soon afterwards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="China_and_Russia">China and Russia</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="China–South Korea relations">China–South Korea relations</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93Taiwan_relations" title="South Korea–Taiwan relations">South Korea–Taiwan relations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="Russia–South Korea relations">Russia–South Korea relations</a></div>
<p>Historically, Korea had close relations with the dynasties in China, and some Korean kingdoms were members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Imperial_Chinese_tributary_system" title="Imperial Chinese tributary system">Imperial Chinese tributary system</a>. The Korean kingdoms also ruled over some Chinese kingdoms including the Khitan people and the Manchurians before the Qing dynasty and received tributes from them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[235]</a></sup> In modern times, before the formation of South Korea, Korean independence fighters worked with Chinese soldiers during the Japanese occupation. However, after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, the People's Republic of China embraced <a href="/wiki/Maoism" title="Maoism">Maoism</a> while South Korea sought close relations with the United States. The PRC assisted North Korea with manpower and supplies during the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a>, and in its aftermath the diplomatic relationship between South Korea and the PRC almost completely ceased. Relations thawed gradually and South Korea and the PRC re-established formal diplomatic relations on 24 August 1992. The two countries sought to improve bilateral relations and lifted the forty-year-old trade embargo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-239">[236]</a></sup> and South Korean–Chinese relations have improved steadily since 1992.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_239-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-239">[236]</a></sup> The Republic of Korea broke off official relations with the <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">Republic of China (Taiwan)</a> upon gaining official relations with the People's Republic of China, which does not recognize <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Taiwan#Position_of_the_People's_Republic_of_China_(PRC)" title="Political status of Taiwan">Taiwan's sovereignty</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[237]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_(2017-09-06)_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1160" data-file-width="1880" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_%282017-09-06%29_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_and_Moon_Jae-in_(2017-09-06)_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>South Korean president <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> meets with Russian president <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a></div></div></div>
<p>China has become South Korea's largest trading partner by far, sending 26% of South Korean exports in 2016 worth $124 billion, as well as an additional $32 billion worth of exports to <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-241">[238]</a></sup> South Korea is also China's 4th largest trading partner, with $93 billion of Chinese imports in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[239]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 2017 deployment of <a href="/wiki/Terminal_High_Altitude_Area_Defense" title="Terminal High Altitude Area Defense">THAAD</a> defense missiles by the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> military in South Korea in response to North Korean missile tests has been protested strongly by the Chinese government, concerned that the technologically advanced missile defense could be used more broadly against China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[240]</a></sup> Relations between the governments have cooled in response, with South Korean commercial and cultural interests in China having been targeted, and Chinese tourism to South Korea having been curtailed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[241]</a></sup> The situation was largely resolved by South Korea making significant military concessions to China in exchange for THAAD, including not deploying any more anti-ballistic missile systems in South Korea and not participating in an alliance between the United States and Japan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea and Russia are participants in the <a href="/wiki/Six-party_talks" title="Six-party talks">Six-party talks</a> on the North Korea's nuclear proliferation issue. Moon Jae-in's administration has focused on increasing South Korea's consumption of natural gas. These plans include re-opening dialogue around a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">natural gas pipeline</a> that would come from <a href="/wiki/Russia" title="Russia">Russia</a> and pass through North Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[243]</a></sup> In June 2018, president <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> became the first South Korean leader to speak in the <a href="/wiki/State_Duma" title="State Duma">Russian Parliament</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[244]</a></sup> On 22 June, Moon Jae-in and Putin signed a document for foundation of free trade area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[245]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Japan">Japan</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93South_Korea_relations" title="Japan–South Korea relations">Japan–South Korea relations</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan%E2%80%93Korea_relations" title="History of Japan–Korea relations">History of Japan–Korea relations</a> and <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_disputes" title="Japan–Korea disputes">Japan–Korea disputes</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="333" data-file-width="500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg/220px-Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg/330px-Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg/440px-Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Liancourt_walleye_view.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks" title="Liancourt Rocks">Liancourt Rocks</a> have become an issue known as the <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks_dispute" title="Liancourt Rocks dispute">Liancourt Rocks dispute</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Korea and Japan have had <a href="/wiki/History_of_Japan%E2%80%93Korea_relations" title="History of Japan–Korea relations">difficult relations since ancient times</a>, but also significant cultural exchange, with Korea acting as the gateway between Asia and Japan. Contemporary perceptions of Japan are still largely defined by <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japan's 35 year colonization of Korea</a> in the 20th century, which is <a href="/wiki/Anti-Japanese_sentiment_in_Korea" title="Anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea">generally regarded in South Korea as having been very negative</a>. Japan is today South Korea's third largest trading partner, with 12% ($46 billion) of exports in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-241">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were no formal diplomatic ties between South Korea and Japan directly after independence the end of World War II in 1945. South Korea and Japan eventually signed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Treaty_on_Basic_Relations_between_Japan_and_the_Republic_of_Korea" title="Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea">Treaty on Basic Relations between Japan and the Republic of Korea</a> in 1965 to establish diplomatic ties. There is heavy <a href="/wiki/Anti-Japanese_sentiment_in_Korea" title="Anti-Japanese sentiment in Korea">anti-Japanese sentiment in South Korea</a> because of a number of unsettled <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_disputes" title="Japan–Korea disputes">Japanese-Korean disputes</a>, many of which stem from the period of <a href="/wiki/Korea_under_Japanese_rule" title="Korea under Japanese rule">Japanese occupation</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Japan%E2%80%93Korea_Treaty_of_1910" title="Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910">Japanese annexation of Korea</a>. During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, more than 100,000 Koreans served in the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Japanese_Army" title="Imperial Japanese Army">Imperial Japanese Army</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[247]</a></sup> Korean women were coerced and forced to serve the Imperial Japanese Army as sexual slaves, called <a href="/wiki/Comfort_women" title="Comfort women">comfort women</a>, in both Korea and throughout the Japanese war fronts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>Longstanding issues such as <a href="/wiki/Japanese_war_crimes" title="Japanese war crimes">Japanese war crimes</a> against Korean civilians, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Historical_revisionism_(negationism)" title="Historical revisionism (negationism)">negationist</a> <a href="/wiki/Japanese_history_textbook_controversies" title="Japanese history textbook controversies">re-writing of Japanese textbooks</a> relating Japanese atrocities during World War II, the territorial disputes over the <a href="/wiki/Liancourt_Rocks" title="Liancourt Rocks">Liancourt Rocks</a>, known in South Korea as "Dokdo" and in Japan as "Takeshima",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[250]</a></sup> and visits by Japanese politicians to the <a href="/wiki/Yasukuni_Shrine" title="Yasukuni Shrine">Yasukuni Shrine</a>, honoring Japanese people (civilians and military) killed during the war continue to trouble Korean-Japanese relations. The Liancourt Rocks were the first Korean territories to be forcibly colonized by Japan in 1905. Although it was again returned to Korea along with the rest of its territory in 1951 with the signing of the Treaty of San Francisco, Japan does not recant on its claims that the Liancourt Rocks are Japanese territory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[251]</a></sup>
In response to then-Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Junichiro_Koizumi" title="Junichiro Koizumi">Junichiro Koizumi</a>'s visits to the Yasukuni Shrine, former <a href="/wiki/President_of_South_Korea" title="President of South Korea">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Roh_Moo-hyun" title="Roh Moo-hyun">Roh Moo-hyun</a> suspended all summit talks between South Korea and Japan in 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[252]</a></sup>
A summit between the nations' leaders was eventually held on 9 February 2018 during the <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">Korean held Winter Olympics</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[253]</a></sup> South Korea asked <a href="/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee" title="International Olympic Committee">the International Olympic Committee (IOC)</a> to ban the Japanese <a href="/wiki/Rising_Sun_Flag" title="Rising Sun Flag">Rising Sun Flag</a> from the <a href="/wiki/2020_Summer_Olympics" title="2020 Summer Olympics">2020 Summer Olympics</a> in Tokyo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[254]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[255]</a></sup> and the IOC said in a statement "sports stadiums should be free of any political demonstration. When concerns arise at games time we look at them on a case-by-case basis."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[256]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Union">European Union</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93European_Union_relations" title="South Korea–European Union relations">South Korea–European Union relations</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) and South Korea are important trading partners, having negotiated a <a href="/wiki/Free_trade_agreement" title="Free trade agreement">free trade agreement</a> for many years since South Korea was designated as a priority FTA partner in 2006. The free trade agreement was approved in September 2010, and took effect on 1 July 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[257]</a></sup> South Korea is the EU's tenth largest trade partner, and the EU has become South Korea's fourth largest export destination. EU trade with South Korea exceeded €90 billion in 2015 and has enjoyed an annual average growth rate of 9.8% between 2003 and 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-EU-261">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>The EU has been the single largest foreign investor in South Korea since 1962, and accounted for almost 45% of all FDI inflows into Korea in 2006. Nevertheless, EU companies have significant problems accessing and operating in the South Korean market because of stringent standards and testing requirements for products and services often creating barriers to trade. Both in its regular bilateral contacts with South Korea and through its FTA with Korea, the EU is seeking to improve this situation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU_261-1"><a href="#cite_note-EU-261">[258]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">United States</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/South_Korea%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="South Korea–United States relations">South Korea–United States relations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:P20210521AS-2069_(51224512406).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1190" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg/220px-P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg/330px-P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg/440px-P20210521AS-2069_%2851224512406%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:P20210521AS-2069_(51224512406).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Moon_Jae-in" title="Moon Jae-in">Moon Jae-in</a> and <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">U.S. President</a> <a href="/wiki/Joe_Biden" title="Joe Biden">Joe Biden</a> having lunch on 21 May 2021, on the Oval Office Patio of the White House</div></div></div>
<p>The close relationship began directly after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, when the United States temporarily administrated Korea for three years (mainly in the South, with the Soviet Union engaged in North Korea) after Japan. Upon the onset of the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> in 1950, U.S. forces were sent to defend against an invasion from North Korea of the South, and subsequently fought <a href="/wiki/United_States_in_the_Korean_War" title="United States in the Korean War">as the largest contributor of UN troops</a>. The United States participation was critical for preventing the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Pusan_Perimeter" title="Battle of Pusan Perimeter">near defeat of the Republic of Korea</a> by northern forces, as well as fighting back for the territory gains that define the South Korean nation today.
</p><p>Following the Armistice, South Korea and the U.S. agreed to a "Mutual Defense Treaty", under which an attack on either party in the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Ocean" title="Pacific Ocean">Pacific area</a> would summon a response from both.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[259]</a></sup> In 1967, South Korea obliged the mutual defense treaty, by sending a large combat troop contingent to support the United States in the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>. The US has <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forces_Korea" title="United States Forces Korea">over 23,000 troops stationed in South Korea</a>, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Eighth_Army" title="US Eighth Army">U.S. Eighth Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Air_Force" title="Seventh Air Force">Seventh Air Force</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander_Naval_Forces_Korea" title="Commander Naval Forces Korea">U.S. Naval Forces Korea</a>. The two nations have strong economic, diplomatic, and military ties, although they have at times disagreed with regard to policies towards North Korea, and with regard to some of South Korea's industrial activities that involve usage of rocket or nuclear technology. There had also been strong anti-American sentiment during certain periods, which has largely moderated in the modern day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[260]</a></sup>
</p><p>The two nations also share a close economic relationship, with the U.S being South Korea's second largest <a href="/wiki/International_trade" title="International trade">trading partner</a>, receiving $66 billion in exports in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto3_241-2"><a href="#cite_note-auto3-241">[238]</a></sup> In 2007, a free trade agreement known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Korea_%E2%80%93_United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="South Korea – United States Free Trade Agreement">Republic of Korea-United States Free Trade Agreement</a> (KORUS FTA) was signed between South Korea and the United States, but its formal implementation was repeatedly delayed, pending approval by the legislative bodies of the two countries. On 12 October 2011, the U.S. Congress passed the long-stalled trade agreement with South Korea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[261]</a></sup> It went into effect on 15 March 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[262]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Armed_Forces" title="Republic of Korea Armed Forces">Republic of Korea Armed Forces</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="Ambox current red Asia Australia.svg" data-file-height="290" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" width="42"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section's <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute">factual accuracy</a> may be compromised due to out-of-date information</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">March 2012</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Unresolved tension with North Korea has prompted South Korea to allocate 2.6% of its GDP and 15% of all government spending to its military (Government share of GDP: 14.967%), while maintaining compulsory conscription for men.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[263]</a></sup> Consequently, South Korea has the world's seventh largest number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_total_troops" title="List of countries by number of total troops">active troops</a> (599,000 in 2018), the world's highest number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_size_of_armed_forces" title="List of countries by size of armed forces">reserve troops</a> (3,100,000 in 2018).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>The South Korean military consists of the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Army" title="Republic of Korea Army">Army</a> (ROKA), the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Navy" title="Republic of Korea Navy">Navy</a> (ROKN), the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Air_Force" title="Republic of Korea Air Force">Air Force</a> (ROKAF), and the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Marine_Corps" title="Republic of Korea Marine Corps">Marine Corps</a> (ROKMC), and reserve forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[265]</a></sup> Many of these forces are concentrated near the <a href="/wiki/Korean_Demilitarized_Zone" title="Korean Demilitarized Zone">Korean Demilitarized Zone</a>. All South Korean males are constitutionally required to serve in the military, typically 18 months. Previous exceptions for South Korean citizens of mixed race no longer apply since 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_(DDG_991)_broadside_view.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="845" data-file-width="1933" decoding="async" height="96" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg/220px-ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg/330px-ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg/440px-ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_%28DDG_991%29_broadside_view.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ROKS_Sejong_the_Great_(DDG_991)_broadside_view.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Navy" title="Republic of Korea Navy">ROKN</a> Sejong the Great, a <a href="/wiki/Sejong_the_Great-class_destroyer" title="Sejong the Great-class destroyer"><i>Sejong the Great</i></a>-class <a href="/wiki/Guided-missile_destroyer" title="Guided-missile destroyer">guided-missile destroyer</a> built by <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Heavy_Industries" title="Hyundai Heavy Industries">Hyundai Heavy Industries</a></div></div></div>
<p>In addition to male conscription in South Korea's sovereign military, 1,800 Korean males are selected every year to serve 18 months in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KATUSA" title="KATUSA">KATUSA</a> Program to further augment the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Forces_Korea" title="United States Forces Korea">United States Forces Korea</a> (USFK).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[267]</a></sup> In 2010, South Korea was spending <a href="/wiki/South_Korean_won" title="South Korean won">₩</a>1.68 trillion in a cost-sharing agreement with the US to provide budgetary support to the US forces in Korea, on top of the ₩29.6 trillion budget for its own military.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:K2_black_panther3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1295" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/K2_black_panther3.jpg/220px-K2_black_panther3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/K2_black_panther3.jpg/330px-K2_black_panther3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/K2_black_panther3.jpg/440px-K2_black_panther3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:K2_black_panther3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The South Korean-developed <a href="/wiki/K2_Black_Panther" title="K2 Black Panther">K2 Black Panther</a>, built by <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Rotem" title="Hyundai Rotem">Hyundai Rotem</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Army" title="Republic of Korea Army">South Korean Army</a> has 2,500 <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">tanks</a> in operation, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/K1A1" title="K1A1">K1A1</a> and <a href="/wiki/K2_Black_Panther" title="K2 Black Panther">K2 Black Panther</a>, which form the backbone of the South Korean army's mechanized armor and infantry forces. A sizable arsenal of many artillery systems, including 1,700 self-propelled <a href="/wiki/M109_howitzer" title="M109 howitzer">K55</a> and <a href="/wiki/K9_Thunder" title="K9 Thunder">K9 Thunder</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Howitzers" title="Howitzers">howitzers</a> and 680 helicopters and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UAVs" title="UAVs">UAVs</a> of numerous types, are assembled to provide additional fire, reconnaissance, and logistics support. South Korea's smaller but more advanced artillery force and wide range of airborne reconnaissance platforms are pivotal in the <a href="/wiki/Counter-battery_fire" title="Counter-battery fire">counter-battery suppression</a> of North Korea's large artillery force, which operates more than 13,000 artillery systems deployed in various state of fortification and mobility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Navy" title="Republic of Korea Navy">South Korean Navy</a> has made its first major transformation into a <a href="/wiki/Blue-water_navy" title="Blue-water navy">blue-water navy</a> through the formation of the Strategic Mobile Fleet, which includes a battle group of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chungmugong_Yi_Sun-sin_class_destroyer" title="Chungmugong Yi Sun-sin class destroyer">Chungmugong Yi Sun-sin class destroyers</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dokdo_class_amphibious_assault_ship" title="Dokdo class amphibious assault ship">Dokdo class amphibious assault ship</a>, <a href="/wiki/Air-independent_propulsion" title="Air-independent propulsion">AIP-driven</a> <a href="/wiki/Type_214_submarine" title="Type 214 submarine">Type 214 submarines</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Sejong_the_Great_class_destroyer" title="King Sejong the Great class destroyer">King Sejong the Great class destroyers</a>, which is equipped with the latest baseline of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aegis_combat_system" title="Aegis combat system">Aegis fleet-defense</a> system that allows the ships to track and destroy multiple cruise missiles and ballistic missiles simultaneously, forming an integral part of South Korea's indigenous missile defense umbrella against the North Korean military's missile threat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[269]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Air_Force" title="Republic of Korea Air Force">South Korean Air Force</a> operates 840 aircraft, making it world's ninth largest air force, including several types of advanced fighters like <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-15K" title="F-15K">F-15K</a>, heavily modified <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/F-16_Fighting_Falcon_variants#KF-16" title="F-16 Fighting Falcon variants">KF-16C/D</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[270]</a></sup> and the indigenous <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T-50_Golden_Eagle" title="T-50 Golden Eagle">T-50 Golden Eagle</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[271]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[272]</a></sup> supported by well-maintained fleets of older fighters such as <a href="/wiki/McDonnell_Douglas_F-4_Phantom_II" title="McDonnell Douglas F-4 Phantom II">F-4E</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northrop_F-5" title="Northrop F-5">KF-5E/F</a> that still effectively serve the air force alongside the more modern aircraft. In an attempt to gain strength in terms of not just numbers but also modernity, the commissioning of four <a href="/wiki/Boeing_737_AEW%26C" title="Boeing 737 AEW&amp;C">Boeing 737 AEW&amp;C</a> aircraft, under Project Peace Eye for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/C4ISTAR" title="C4ISTAR">centralized intelligence gathering and analysis</a> on a modern battlefield, will enhance the fighters' and other support aircraft's ability to perform their missions with awareness and precision.
</p><p>In May 2011, <a href="/wiki/Korea_Aerospace_Industries" title="Korea Aerospace Industries">Korea Aerospace Industries</a> Ltd., South Korea's largest plane maker, signed a $400 million deal to sell 16 T-50 Golden Eagle trainer jets to <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, making South Korea the first country in Asia to export supersonic jets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[273]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1256" data-file-width="1967" decoding="async" height="140" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KAI_FA-50_Fighting_Eagle_of_ROK_AirForce_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Korea_Air_Force" title="Republic of Korea Air Force">ROKAF</a> <a href="/wiki/KAI_T-50_Golden_Eagle" title="KAI T-50 Golden Eagle">FA-50</a>, a supersonic combat aircraft developed by <a href="/wiki/Korea_Aerospace_Industries" title="Korea Aerospace Industries">Korea Aerospace Industries</a></div></div></div>
<p>From time to time, South Korea has sent its troops overseas to assist American forces. It has participated in most major conflicts that the United States has been involved in the past 50 years. South Korea dispatched 325,517 troops to fight alongside American, Australian, <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Filipino</a>, New Zealand and <a href="/wiki/South_Vietnam" title="South Vietnam">South Vietnamese</a> soldiers in the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a>, with a peak strength of 50,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[274]</a></sup> In 2004, South Korea sent 3,300 troops of the <a href="/wiki/Zaytun_Division" title="Zaytun Division">Zaytun Division</a> to help re-building in northern <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">Iraq</a>, and was the third largest contributor in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multinational_force_in_Iraq" title="Multinational force in Iraq">coalition forces</a> after only the US and Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[275]</a></sup> Beginning in 2001, South Korea had so far deployed 24,000 troops in the Middle East region to support the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_on_Terrorism" title="War on Terrorism">War on Terrorism</a>. A further 1,800 were deployed since 2007 to reinforce UN peacekeeping forces in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_(7438321572).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1777" data-file-width="2953" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg/220px-%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg/330px-%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg/440px-%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_%287438321572%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:%ED%95%B4%EA%B5%B0_%EB%8F%85%EB%8F%84%ED%95%A8_(7438321572).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/ROKS_Dokdo" title="ROKS Dokdo">ROKS Dokdo</a>, the lead ship of the <a href="/wiki/Dokdo-class_amphibious_assault_ship" title="Dokdo-class amphibious assault ship"><i>Dokdo</i>-class</a> <a href="/wiki/Amphibious_assault_ship" title="Amphibious assault ship">amphibious assault ship</a>, built by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hanjin_Heavy_Industries" title="Hanjin Heavy Industries">Hanjin Heavy Industries</a></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_States_contingent">United States contingent</span></h3>
<p>The United States has stationed a substantial contingent of troops to defend South Korea. There are approximately 28,500 U.S. military personnel stationed in South Korea,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[276]</a></sup> most of them serving one year unaccompanied tours. The U.S. troops, which are primarily ground and air units, are assigned to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USFK" title="USFK">USFK</a> and mainly assigned to the <a href="/wiki/Eighth_United_States_Army" title="Eighth United States Army">Eighth United States Army</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Army" title="U.S. Army">U.S. Army</a> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Air_Force" title="Seventh Air Force">Seventh Air Force</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Air_Force" title="U.S. Air Force">U.S. Air Force</a>. They are stationed in installations at <a href="/wiki/Osan" title="Osan">Osan</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kunsan" title="Kunsan">Kunsan</a>, Yongsan, <a href="/wiki/Dongducheon" title="Dongducheon">Dongducheon</a>, Sungbuk, <a href="/wiki/Camp_Humphreys" title="Camp Humphreys">Camp Humphreys</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Daegu" title="Daegu">Daegu</a>, as well as at <a href="/wiki/Camp_Bonifas" title="Camp Bonifas">Camp Bonifas</a> in the DMZ <a href="/wiki/Joint_Security_Area" title="Joint Security Area">Joint Security Area</a>.
</p><p>A fully functioning <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Command_(Korea)" title="United Nations Command (Korea)">UN Command</a> is at the top of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chain_of_command" title="Chain of command">chain of command</a> of all forces in South Korea, including the U.S. forces and the entire South Korean military – if a sudden escalation of war between North and South Korea were to occur the United States would assume control of the South Korean armed forces in all military and paramilitary moves. There has been long-term agreement between the United States and South Korea that South Korea should eventually assume the lead for its own defense. This transition to a South Korean command has been slow and often postponed, although it is currently scheduled to occur in the early 2020s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[277]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conscientious_objection">Conscientious objection</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="box-Update plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Update" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="Ambox current red Asia Australia.svg" data-file-height="290" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="34" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/63px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg/84px-Ambox_current_red_Asia_Australia.svg.png 2x" width="42"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section needs to be <b>updated</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2019</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Male citizens who refuse or reject to undertake military services because of conscientious objection are typically imprisoned, with over 600 individuals usually imprisoned at any given time; more than the rest of the world put together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[278]</a></sup> The vast majority of these are young men from the <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a> Christian denomination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[279]</a></sup>
See <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_South_Korea" title="Conscription in South Korea">Conscription in South Korea</a>. However, in a court ruling of 2018, conscientious objectors were permitted to reject military service.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[280]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_South_Korea" title="Economy of South Korea">Economy of South Korea</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_companies_of_South_Korea" title="List of largest companies of South Korea">List of largest companies of South Korea</a></div>
<table class="wikitable" style="float: right; margin-left: 10px;">

<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BOK_main_office3.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="402" data-file-width="531" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/BOK_main_office3.jpg/200px-BOK_main_office3.jpg" of Korea">Bank of Korea</a>, the central bank of the South Korea and issuer of the <a href="/wiki/South_Korean_won" title="South Korean won">South Korean won</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Samsung_headquarters.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Samsung_headquarters.jpg/200px-Samsung_headquarters.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Samsung_headquarters.jpg/300px-Samsung_headquarters.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Samsung_headquarters.jpg/400px-Samsung_headquarters.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The Samsung headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Samsung_Town" title="Samsung Town">Samsung Town</a>, located in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seocho-gu" title="Seocho-gu">Seocho-gu</a>, Seoul</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2340" data-file-width="4160" decoding="async" height="113" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg/200px-Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg/300px-Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg/400px-Helicopter_view_of_Seoul.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Lotte_World_Tower" title="Lotte World Tower">Lotte World Tower</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Songpa-gu" title="Songpa-gu">Songpa-gu</a>, Seoul, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_South_Korea" title="List of tallest buildings in South Korea">tallest building in South Korea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings" title="List of tallest buildings">5th tallest in the world</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>South Korea's <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[284]</a></sup> ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">10th</a> nominal<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[285]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">13th</a> purchasing power parity GDP in the world, identifying it as one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>. It is a <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed country</a> with a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-income_economies" title="High-income economies">high-income economy</a> and is the most industrialized member country of the <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a>. South Korean brands such as <a href="/wiki/LG_Electronics" title="LG Electronics">LG Electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a> are internationally famous and garnered South Korea's reputation for its quality electronics and other manufactured goods.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>Its massive investment in education has taken the country from mass illiteracy to a major international technological powerhouse. The country's national economy benefits from a highly skilled workforce and is among the most educated countries in the world with one of the highest percentages of its citizens holding a tertiary education degree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OECD_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-290">[287]</a></sup> South Korea's economy was one of the world's fastest-growing from the early 1960s to the late 1990s, and was still one of the fastest-growing developed countries in the 2000s, along with Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan, the other three <a href="/wiki/Four_Asian_Tigers" title="Four Asian Tigers">Asian Tigers</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[288]</a></sup> It recorded the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_per_capita_growth_rate" title="List of countries by GDP (real) per capita growth rate">fastest rise in average GDP per capita</a> in the world between 1980 and 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[289]</a></sup> South Koreans refer to this growth as the <a href="/wiki/Miracle_on_the_Han_River" title="Miracle on the Han River">Miracle on the Han River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[290]</a></sup> The South Korean economy is heavily dependent on international trade, and in 2014, South Korea was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">fifth-largest exporter</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">seventh-largest importer</a> in the world.
</p><p>Despite the South Korean economy's high growth potential and apparent structural stability, the country suffers damage to its credit rating in the stock market because of the belligerence of North Korea in times of deep military crises, which has an adverse effect on South Korean financial markets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kcredit_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-kcredit-294">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[292]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> compliments the resilience of the South Korean economy against various economic crises, citing low state debt and high fiscal reserves that can quickly be mobilized to address financial emergencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[293]</a></sup> Although it was severely harmed by the <a href="/wiki/1997_Asian_financial_crisis" title="1997 Asian financial crisis">1997 Asian financial crisis</a>, the South Korean economy managed a rapid recovery and subsequently tripled its GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[294]</a></sup>
</p><p>Furthermore, South Korea was one of the few developed countries that were able to avoid a <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">recession</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">global financial crisis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[295]</a></sup> Its economic growth rate reached 6.2 percent in 2010 (the fastest growth for eight years after significant growth by 7.2 percent in 2002),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[296]</a></sup> a sharp recovery from economic growth rates of 2.3% in 2008 and 0.2% in 2009 during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">Great Recession</a>. The unemployment rate in South Korea also remained low in 2009, at 3.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea became a member of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD) in 1996.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[298]</a></sup>
</p><p>The following list includes the largest South Korean companies by revenue in 2017 who are all listed as part of the <a href="/wiki/Fortune_Global_500" title="Fortune Global 500">Fortune Global 500</a>:
</p>

<h3><span id="Transportation.2C_energy_and_infrastructure"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation,_energy_and_infrastructure">Transportation, energy and infrastructure</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_South_Korea" title="Transport in South Korea">Transport in South Korea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_South_Korea" title="Energy in South Korea">Energy in South Korea</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2172" data-file-width="3380" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg/200px-Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg/300px-Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg/400px-Incheon_Airport_Maglev_1-04.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Incheon_International_Airport" title="Incheon International Airport">Incheon International Airport</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Incheon_Airport_Maglev" title="Incheon Airport Maglev">Maglev</a> station</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2238" data-file-width="3012" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg/200px-HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg/300px-HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg/400px-HEMU-430X_Test_run.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">South Korea developed the <a href="/wiki/HEMU-430X" title="HEMU-430X">HEMU 430X</a> <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed train</a>, which can travel at over 430 km/h (267 mph), making South Korea the world's fourth country after <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> to develop a high-speed train running above 420 km/h on conventional rails.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2368" data-file-width="3908" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg/200px-Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg/300px-Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg/400px-Daegu_Metro_Line_3.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Daegu_Metro_Line_3" title="Daegu Metro Line 3">Daegu Metro Line 3</a> monorail</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>South Korea has a technologically advanced transport network consisting of high-speed railways, highways, bus routes, ferry services, and air routes that crisscross the country. <a href="/wiki/Korea_Expressway_Corporation" title="Korea Expressway Corporation">Korea Expressway Corporation</a> operates the toll highways and service amenities en route.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Korail" title="Korail">Korail</a> provides frequent train services to all major South Korean cities. Two rail lines, <a href="/wiki/Gyeongui_Line" title="Gyeongui Line">Gyeongui</a> and <a href="/wiki/Donghae_Bukbu_Line" title="Donghae Bukbu Line">Donghae Bukbu Line</a>, to North Korea are now being reconnected. The Korean <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">high-speed rail</a> system, <a href="/wiki/Korea_Train_Express" title="Korea Train Express">KTX</a>, provides high-speed service along <a href="/wiki/Gyeongbu_Line" title="Gyeongbu Line">Gyeongbu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Honam_Line" title="Honam Line">Honam Line</a>. Major cities including Seoul, <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Incheon" title="Incheon">Incheon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daegu" title="Daegu">Daegu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Daejeon" title="Daejeon">Daejeon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gwangju" title="Gwangju">Gwangju</a> have urban rapid transit systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[300]</a></sup> Express bus terminals are available in most cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea's main gateway and largest airport is <a href="/wiki/Incheon_International_Airport" title="Incheon International Airport">Incheon International Airport</a>, serving <span class="nowrap">58 million</span> passengers in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[302]</a></sup> Other international airports include <a href="/wiki/Gimpo_International_Airport" title="Gimpo International Airport">Gimpo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gimhae_International_Airport" title="Gimhae International Airport">Busan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jeju_International_Airport" title="Jeju International Airport">Jeju</a>. There are also many airports that were built as part of the infrastructure boom but are barely used.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[303]</a></sup> There are also many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heliports" title="Heliports">heliports</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>The national carrier, <a href="/wiki/Korean_Air" title="Korean Air">Korean Air</a> served over 26,800,000 passengers, including almost 19,000,000 international passengers in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[305]</a></sup> A second carrier, <a href="/wiki/Asiana_Airlines" title="Asiana Airlines">Asiana Airlines</a> also serves domestic and international traffic. Combined, South Korean airlines serve 297 international routes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[306]</a></sup> Smaller airlines, such as <a href="/wiki/Jeju_Air" title="Jeju Air">Jeju Air</a>, provide domestic service with lower fares.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[307]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea is the world's fifth-largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a> producer and the second-largest in Asia as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-koreanuke_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-koreanuke-311">[308]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_South_Korea" title="Nuclear power in South Korea">Nuclear power in South Korea</a> supplies 45% of electricity production, and research is very active with investigation into a variety of advanced reactors, including a small modular reactor, a liquid-metal fast/<a href="/wiki/Nuclear_transmutation#Artificial_transmutation_of_nuclear_waste" title="Nuclear transmutation">transmutation</a> reactor and a high-temperature <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a> generation design. Fuel production and waste handling technologies have also been developed locally. It is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/ITER" title="ITER">ITER</a> project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea is an emerging exporter of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactors" title="Nuclear reactors">nuclear reactors</a>, having concluded agreements with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UAE" title="UAE">UAE</a> to build and maintain four advanced nuclear reactors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[310]</a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> for a research nuclear reactor,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[312]</a></sup> and with <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a> for construction and repair of heavy-water nuclear reactors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-argentinanuke_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-argentinanuke-317">[314]</a></sup> As of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=South_Korea&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, South Korea and <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a> are in negotiations regarding construction of two nuclear reactors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[315]</a></sup> South Korea is also preparing to bid on construction of a light-water nuclear reactor for Argentina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-argentinanuke_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-argentinanuke-317">[314]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea is not allowed to <a href="/wiki/Enriched_uranium" title="Enriched uranium">enrich uranium</a> or develop traditional uranium enrichment technology on its own, because of US political pressure,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[316]</a></sup> unlike most major nuclear powers such as Japan, Germany, and France, competitors of South Korea in the international nuclear market. This impediment to South Korea's indigenous nuclear industrial undertaking has sparked occasional diplomatic rows between the two allies. While South Korea is successful in exporting its electricity-generating nuclear technology and nuclear reactors, it cannot capitalize on the <a href="/wiki/Uranium_market" title="Uranium market">market for nuclear enrichment facilities and refineries</a>, preventing it from further expanding its export niche. South Korea has sought unique technologies such as <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing#Pyroprocessing" title="Nuclear reprocessing">pyroprocessing</a> to circumvent these obstacles and seek a more advantageous competition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[317]</a></sup> The US has recently been wary of South Korea's burgeoning nuclear program, which South Korea insists will be for civilian use only.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-koreanuke_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-koreanuke-311">[308]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea is the third highest ranked Asian country in the World Economic Forum's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Network_Readiness_Index" title="Network Readiness Index">Network Readiness Index</a> (NRI) after Singapore and Hong Kong respectively – an indicator for determining the development level of a country's information and communication technologies. South Korea ranked number 10 overall in the 2014 NRI ranking, up from 11 in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_South_Korea" title="Tourism in South Korea">Tourism in South Korea</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="801" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg/220px-Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg/330px-Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg/440px-Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Haeundae_Beach_NightView.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Haeundae_Beach" title="Haeundae Beach">Haeundae Beach</a> in <a href="/wiki/Busan" title="Busan">Busan</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2016, 17 million foreign tourists visited South Korea<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[320]</a></sup> With rising tourist prospects, especially from foreign countries outside of Asia, the South Korean government has set a target of attracting 20 million foreign tourists a year by 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korean tourism is driven by many factors, including the prominence of Korean pop culture such as <a href="/wiki/K-pop" title="K-pop">South Korean pop music</a> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_drama" title="Korean drama">television dramas</a>, known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Korean_Wave" title="Korean Wave">Korean Wave</a> or (Hallyu), has gained popularity throughout East Asia. The Hyundai Research Institute reported that the Korean Wave has a direct impact in encouraging direct foreign investment back into the country through demand for products, and the tourism industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Korea_Times_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-Korea_Times-325">[322]</a></sup> Among East Asian countries, China was the most receptive, investing 1.4 billion in South Korea, with much of the investment within its service sector, a sevenfold increase from 2001. According to an analysis by economist Han Sang-Wan, a 1 percent increase in the exports of Korean cultural content pushes consumer goods exports up 0.083 percent while a 1 percent increase in Korean pop content exports to a country produces a 0.019 percent bump in tourism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Korea_Times_325-1"><a href="#cite_note-Korea_Times-325">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="South_Korean_National_Pension_System">South Korean National Pension System</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="box-Split plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-move" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="60" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Split-arrows.svg/50px-Split-arrows.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Split-arrows.svg/75px-Split-arrows.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Split-arrows.svg/100px-Split-arrows.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">It has been suggested that  this article should be <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Splitting" title="Wikipedia:Splitting">split</a></b> into multiple articles. (<a href="/wiki/Talk:South_Korea" title="Talk:South Korea">discuss</a>)  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">November 2020</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Pension_policy_in_South_Korea" title="Pension policy in South Korea">South Korean pension system</a> was created to provide benefits to persons reaching old age, families and persons stricken with death of their primary breadwinner, and for the purposes of stabilizing its nations welfare state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Korea_Labor_Institute_1998_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-Korea_Labor_Institute_1998-326">[323]</a></sup> South Korea's pension system structure is primarily based on taxation and is income-related. In 2007 there was a total of 18,367,000 insured individuals with only around 511,000 persons excluded from mandatory contribution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[324]</a></sup> The current pension system is divided into four categories distributing benefits to participants through national, military personnel, governmental, and private school teacher pension schemes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[325]</a></sup> The national pension scheme is the primary welfare system providing allowances to the majority of persons. Eligibility for the national pension scheme is not dependent on income but on age and residence, where those between the ages of 18 to 59 are covered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Pension_Service_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-National_Pension_Service-329">[326]</a></sup> Any one who is under the age of 18 are dependents of someone who is covered or under a special exclusion where they are allowed to alternative provisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SSA.GOV_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-SSA.GOV-330">[327]</a></sup> The national pension scheme is divided into four categories of insured persons – the workplace-based insured, the individually insured, the voluntarily insured, and the voluntarily and continuously insured.
</p><p>Employees between the ages of 18 to 59 are covered under the workplace-based pension scheme and contribute 4.5% of their gross monthly earnings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Korea_Labor_Institute_1998_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-Korea_Labor_Institute_1998-326">[323]</a></sup> The national pension covers employees who work in firms that employ five or more employees, fishermen, farmers, and the self-employed in both rural and urban areas. Employers are also covered under the workplace-based pension scheme and help cover their employees obligated 9% contribution by providing the remaining 4.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SSA.GOV_330-1"><a href="#cite_note-SSA.GOV-330">[327]</a></sup> Anyone who is not employed, of the age of 60 or above, and excluded by article 6 of the National Pension Act<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Bank_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank-331">[328]</a></sup> but of the ages between 18 and 59, is covered under the individually insured pension scheme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Bank_331-1"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank-331">[328]</a></sup> Persons covered by the individually insured pension scheme are in charge of paying the entire 9% contribution themselves. Voluntarily insured persons are not subjected to mandatory coverage but can choose to be. This category comprises retirees who voluntarily choose to have additional benefits, individuals under the age of 27 without income, and individuals whose spouses are covered under a public welfare system, whether military, governmental, or private school teacher pensions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Pension_Service_329-1"><a href="#cite_note-National_Pension_Service-329">[326]</a></sup> Like the Individually insured persons, they too are in charge of covering the full amount of the contribution. Voluntarily and continuously insured persons consists of individuals 60 years of age who want to fulfill the minimum insured period of 20 years to qualify for old age pension benefits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Bank_331-2"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank-331">[328]</a></sup> Excluding the workplace-based insured persons, all the other insured persons personally cover their own 9% contribution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Pension_Service_329-2"><a href="#cite_note-National_Pension_Service-329">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>South Korea's old-age pension scheme covers individuals age 60 or older for the rest of their life as long as they have satisfied the minimum of 20 years of national pension coverage beforehand.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SSA.GOV_330-2"><a href="#cite_note-SSA.GOV-330">[327]</a></sup> Individuals with a minimum of 10 years covered under the national pension scheme and who are 60 years of age are able to be covered by under a 'reduced old-age pension' scheme. There also is an 'active old-age pension' scheme that covers individuals age 60 to 65 engaged in activities yielding earned income. Individuals age of 55 and younger than 60 who are not engaged in activities yielding earned income are eligible to be covered under the 'early old-age pension' scheme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Bank_331-3"><a href="#cite_note-World_Bank-331">[328]</a></sup> Around 60% of all Korean elders, age 65 and over are entitled to a 5% benefit of their past average income at an average of 90,000 <a href="/wiki/Korean_won" title="Korean won">Korean Won</a> (KRW).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[329]</a></sup> Basic old-age pension schemes covered individuals 65 years of age who earned below an amount set by presidential order. In 2010, that ceiling was 700,000 KRW for a single individual and 1,120,000 for a couple, equivalent to around $600.00 and $960.00.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SSA.GOV_330-3"><a href="#cite_note-SSA.GOV-330">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Korea" title="History of science and technology in Korea">History of science and technology in Korea</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Korean_inventions_and_discoveries" title="List of Korean inventions and discoveries">List of Korean inventions and discoveries</a></div>
