<li id="cite_note-30"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-30">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source" id="CITEREF이덕일">이덕일. <a class="external text" href="http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2008/08/14/2008081401512.html" rel="nofollow"><bdi lang="ko">[이덕일 사랑] 대~한민국</bdi></a>.  <bdi lang="ko">조선닷컴</bdi> (in Korean). Chosun Ilbo<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">2 July</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%5B%EC%9D%B4%EB%8D%95%EC%9D%BC+%EC%82%AC%EB%9E%91%5D+%EB%8C%80~%ED%95%9C%EB%AF%BC%EA%B5%AD&amp;rft.pub=Chosun+Ilbo&amp;rft.au=%EC%9D%B4%EB%8D%95%EC%9D%BC&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.chosun.com%2Fsite%2Fdata%2Fhtml_dir%2F2008%2F08%2F14%2F2008081401512.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-unloved-31"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-unloved_31-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-unloved_31-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMyers2016"><a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Myers, Brian Reynolds</a> (28 December 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180313210134/http://sthelepress.com/index.php/2016/12/28/still-the-unloved-republic/" rel="nofollow">"Still the Unloved Republic"</a>. <i>Sthele Press</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://sthelepress.com/index.php/2016/12/28/still-the-unloved-republic/" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 13 March 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 June</span> 2019</span>. <q><i>Taehan minguk</i>. In English it is translated as Republic of Korea or South Korea, names which to us foreigners denote the state as a political entity distinct from its northern neighbor. To most people here, however, <i>Taehan minguk</i> conveys that sense only when used in contrastive proximity with the word <i>Pukhan</i> (North Korea). Ask South Koreans when the <i>Taehan minguk</i> was established; more will answer '5000 years ago' than 'in 1948,' because to them it is simply the full name for <i>Hanguk</i>, Korea, the homeland. That’s all it meant to most people who shouted those four syllables so proudly during the World Cup in 2002.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Sthele+Press&amp;rft.atitle=Still+the+Unloved+Republic&amp;rft.date=2016-12-28&amp;rft.aulast=Myers&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian+Reynolds&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fsthelepress.com%2Findex.php%2F2016%2F12%2F28%2Fstill-the-unloved-republic%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-thefreelibrary.com-32"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-thefreelibrary.com_32-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFMyers2018"><a href="/wiki/Brian_Reynolds_Myers" title="Brian Reynolds Myers">Myers, Brian Reynolds</a> (20 May 2018). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20180520092751/https://www.thefreelibrary.com/North+Korea's+state-loyalty+advantage.-a0274114570" rel="nofollow">"North Korea's state-loyalty advantage"</a>. <i>Free Online Library</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="https://www.thefreelibrary.com/North+Korea%27s+state-loyalty+advantage.-a0274114570" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 20 May 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">26 May</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Free+Online+Library&amp;rft.atitle=North+Korea%27s+state-loyalty+advantage.&amp;rft.date=2018-05-20&amp;rft.aulast=Myers&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian+Reynolds&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.thefreelibrary.com%2FNorth%2BKorea%2527s%2Bstate-loyalty%2Badvantage.-a0274114570&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-print_c-33"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-print_c_33-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-print_c_33-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ht/07/eak.html" rel="nofollow">"Korea, 1000–1400 A.D. | Chronology | Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History"</a>. The Metropolitan Museum of Art<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">19 August</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Korea%2C+1000%E2%80%931400+A.D.+%7C+Chronology+%7C+Heilbrunn+Timeline+of+Art+History&amp;rft.pub=The+Metropolitan+Museum+of+Art&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.metmuseum.org%2Ftoah%2Fht%2F07%2Feak.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation pressrelease cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.rom.on.ca/news/releases/public.php?mediakey=sg1yebpnv8" rel="nofollow">"Ancient civilizations"</a> (Press release). Canada: Royal Ontario Museum. 12 December 2005<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">25 April</span> 2010</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Ancient+civilizations&amp;rft.place=Canada&amp;rft.pub=Royal+Ontario+Museum&amp;rft.date=2005-12-12&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rom.on.ca%2Fnews%2Freleases%2Fpublic.php%3Fmediakey%3Dsg1yebpnv8&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080302014245/http://www.opm.go.kr/warp/webapp/content/view?meta_id=english&amp;id=35" rel="nofollow">"Prehistoric Korea"</a>. <i>About Korea</i>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.opm.go.kr/warp/webapp/content/view?meta_id=english&amp;id=35" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 2 March 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 July</span> 2008</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=About+Korea&amp;rft.atitle=Prehistoric+Korea&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.opm.go.kr%2Fwarp%2Fwebapp%2Fcontent%2Fview%3Fmeta_id%3Denglish%26id%3D35&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span>, Office of the Prime Minister.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-koreashistory-36"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-koreashistory_36-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20100128065300/http://www.asianinfo.org/asianinfo/korea/history.htm" rel="nofollow">"Korea's History"</a>. Asian Shravan. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.asianinfo.org/asianinfo/korea/history.htm" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 28 January 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">17 February</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Korea%27s+History&amp;rft.pub=Asian+Shravan&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.asianinfo.org%2Fasianinfo%2Fkorea%2Fhistory.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-DangunGija-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-DangunGija_37-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-DangunGija_37-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">* <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSeth2010">Seth, Michael J. (2010). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WJtMGXyGlUEC&amp;pg=PA443" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Korea: From Antiquity to the Present</i></a>. Rowman &amp; Littlefield Publishers. p. 443. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7425-6717-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7425-6717-7"><bdi>978-0-7425-6717-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Korea%3A+From+Antiquity+to+the+Present&amp;rft.pages=443&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield+Publishers&amp;rft.date=2010&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7425-6717-7&amp;rft.aulast=Seth&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael+J.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWJtMGXyGlUEC%26pg%3DPA443&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span>
<dl><dd>"An extreme manifestation of nationalism and the family cult was the revival of interest in Tangun, the mythical founder of the first Korean state... Most textbooks and professional historians, however, treat him as a myth."</dd></dl>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFStark2008">Stark, Miriam T. (2008). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=z4_bT2SJ-HUC&amp;pg=PA49" rel="nofollow"><i>Archaeology of Asia</i></a>. John Wiley &amp; Sons. p. 49. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-5303-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4051-5303-4"><bdi>978-1-4051-5303-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Archaeology+of+Asia&amp;rft.pages=49&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons&amp;rft.date=2008&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4051-5303-4&amp;rft.aulast=Stark&amp;rft.aufirst=Miriam+T.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dz4_bT2SJ-HUC%26pg%3DPA49&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul>
<dl><dd>"Although Kija may have truly existed as a historical figure, Tangun is more problematical."</dd></dl>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFSchmid2013">Schmid, Andre (2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=lVgaAwAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA269" rel="nofollow"><i>Korea Between Empires</i></a>. Columbia University Press. p. 270. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-50630-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-50630-4"><bdi>978-0-231-50630-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korea+Between+Empires&amp;rft.pages=270&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-50630-4&amp;rft.aulast=Schmid&amp;rft.aufirst=Andre&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DlVgaAwAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA269&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul>
<dl><dd>"Most [Korean historians] treat the [Tangun] myth as a later creation."</dd></dl>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFPeterson2009">Peterson, Mark (2009). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ByIo1D9RY40C&amp;pg=PA5" rel="nofollow"><i>Brief History of Korea</i></a>. Infobase Publishing. p. 5. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4381-2738-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4381-2738-5"><bdi>978-1-4381-2738-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Brief+History+of+Korea&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=Infobase+Publishing&amp;rft.date=2009&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4381-2738-5&amp;rft.aulast=Peterson&amp;rft.aufirst=Mark&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DByIo1D9RY40C%26pg%3DPA5&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul>
<dl><dd>"The Tangun myth became more popular with groups that wanted Korea to be independent; the Kija myth was more useful to those who wanted to show that Korea had a strong affinity to China."</dd></dl>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHulbert2014">Hulbert, H. B. (2014). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=WdusAgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA73" rel="nofollow"><i>The History of Korea</i></a>. Routledge. p. 73. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-317-84941-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-317-84941-4"><bdi>978-1-317-84941-4</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+History+of+Korea&amp;rft.pages=73&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-317-84941-4&amp;rft.aulast=Hulbert&amp;rft.aufirst=H.+B.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DWdusAgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA73&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul>
<dl><dd>"If a choice is to be made between them, one is faced with the fact that the Tangun, with his supernatural origin, is more clearly a mythological figure than Kija."</dd></dl>
</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-45"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-45">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFYiPakYun2005">Yi, Hyŏn-hŭi; Pak, Sŏng-su; Yun, Nae-hyŏn (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=KO8MAQAAMAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>New history of Korea</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-46"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-46">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHall1988">Hall, John Whitney (1988). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=A3_6lp8IOK8C&amp;q=%22The+reign+of+King+Kwanggaet%27o+is+thought+of+as+Koguryo%27s+golden+age+of+political+might+and+Buddhist+splendor.%22" rel="nofollow"><i>The Cambridge History of Japan</i></a>. <li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGrant2011">Grant, Reg G. (2011). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=s4njwZGrZg4C&amp;pg=PA104" rel="nofollow"><i>1001 Battles That Changed the Course of World History</i></a>. Universe Pub. p. 104. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7893-2233-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7893-2233-3"><bdi>978-0-7893-2233-3</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 November</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=1001+Battles+That+Changed+the+Course+of+World+History&amp;rft.pages=104&amp;rft.pub=Universe+Pub.&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7893-2233-3&amp;rft.aulast=Grant&amp;rft.aufirst=Reg+G.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Ds4njwZGrZg4C%26pg%3DPA104&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBedeski2007">Bedeski, Robert (12 March 2007). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=iNl9AgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA90" rel="nofollow"><i>Human Security and the Chinese State: Historical Transformations and the Modern Quest for Sovereignty</i></a>. Routledge. p. 90. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-134-12597-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-134-12597-5"><bdi>978-1-134-12597-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 November</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Human+Security+and+the+Chinese+State%3A+Historical+Transformations+and+the+Modern+Quest+for+Sovereignty&amp;rft.pages=90&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2007-03-12&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-134-12597-5&amp;rft.aulast=Bedeski&amp;rft.aufirst=Robert&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DiNl9AgAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA90&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFYi1984">Yi, Ki-baek (1984). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=g2mdVwXpMzwC&amp;pg=PA47" rel="nofollow"><i>A New History of Korea</i></a>. Harvard University Press. p. 47. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-61576-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-61576-2"><bdi>978-0-674-61576-2</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">29 July</span> 2016</span>. <q>Koguryŏ was the first to open hostilities, with a bold assault across the Liao River against Liao-hsi, in 598. The Sui emperor, Wen Ti, launched a retaliatory attack on Koguryŏ but met with reverses and turned back in mid-course. Yang Ti, the next Sui emperor, proceeded in 612 to mount an invasion of unprecedented magnitude, marshalling a huge force said to number over a million men. And when his armies failed to take Liao-tung Fortress (modern Liao-yang), the anchor of Koguryŏ's first line of defense, he had a nearly a third of his forces, some 300,000 strong, break off the battle there and strike directly at the Koguryŏ capital of P'yŏngyang. But the Sui army was lured into a trap by the famed Koguryŏ commander Ŭlchi Mundŏk, and suffered a calamitous defeat at the Salsu (Ch'ŏngch'ŏn) River. It is said that only 2,700 of the 300,000 Sui soldiers who had crossed the Yalu survived to find their way back, and the Sui emperor now lifted the siege of Liao-tung Fortress and withdrew his forces to China proper. Yang Ti continued to send his armies against Koguryŏ but again without success, and before long his war-weakened empire crumbled.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+New+History+of+Korea&amp;rft.pages=47&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-61576-2&amp;rft.aulast=Yi&amp;rft.aufirst=Ki-baek&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3Dg2mdVwXpMzwC%26pg%3DPA47&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFNahm2005">Nahm, Andrew C. (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/panoramaof5000ye0000nahm/page/18" rel="nofollow"><i>A Panorama of 5000 Years: Korean History</i></a> (Second revised ed.). Seoul: Hollym International Corporation. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/panoramaof5000ye0000nahm/page/18" rel="nofollow">18</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-930878-68-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-930878-68-9"><bdi>978-0-930878-68-9</bdi></a>. <q>China, which had been split into many states since the early 3rd century, was reunified by the Sui dynasty at the end of the 6th century. Soon after that, Sui China mobilized a large number of troops and launched war against Koguryŏ. However, the people of Koguryŏ were united and they were able to repel the Chinese aggressors. In 612, Sui troops invaded Korea again, but Koguryŏ forces fought bravely and destroyed Sui troops everywhere. General Ŭlchi Mundŏk of Koguryŏ completely wiped out some 300,000 Sui troops which came across the Yalu River in the battles near the Salsu River (now Ch'ŏngch'ŏn River) with his ingenious military tactics. Only 2,700 Sui troops were able to flee from Korea. The Sui dynasty, which wasted so much energy and manpower in aggressive wars against Koguryŏ, fell in 618.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Panorama+of+5000+Years%3A+Korean+History&amp;rft.place=Seoul&amp;rft.pages=18&amp;rft.edition=Second+revised&amp;rft.pub=Hollym+International+Corporation&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-930878-68-9&amp;rft.aulast=Nahm&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew+C.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fpanoramaof5000ye0000nahm%2Fpage%2F18&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul>
</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFEbreyWalthallPalais2006">Ebrey, Patricia Buckley; Walthall, Anne; Palais, James B. (2006). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=0entAAAAMAAJ&amp;q=%22Paekche+was+probably+the+most+important+maritime+nation+in+the+late+fourth+century%22" rel="nofollow"><i>East Asia: A Cultural, Social, and Political History</i></a>. Houghton Mifflin. p. 123. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-618-13384-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-618-13384-0"><bdi>978-0-618-13384-0</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">12 September</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=East+Asia%3A+A+Cultural%2C+Social%2C+and+Political+History&amp;rft.pages=123&amp;rft.pub=Houghton+Mifflin&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-618-13384-0&amp;rft.aulast=Ebrey&amp;rft.aufirst=Patricia+Buckley&amp;rft.au=Walthall%2C+Anne&amp;rft.au=Palais%2C+James+B.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D0entAAAAMAAJ%26q%3D%2522Paekche%2Bwas%2Bprobably%2Bthe%2Bmost%2Bimportant%2Bmaritime%2Bnation%2Bin%2Bthe%2Blate%2Bfourth%2Bcentury%2522&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKitagawa2013">Kitagawa, Joseph (5 September 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=9fyzAAAAQBAJ&amp;q=%22Of+vital+importance+for+the+dissemination+of+Buddhism+throughout+East+Asia%2C+however%2C+was+Paekche%27s+nautical+skill%2C+which+made+the+kingdom+the+Phoenicia+of+medieval+East+Asia.%22" rel="nofollow"><i>The Religious Traditions of Asia: Religion, History, and Culture</i></a>. Routledge. p. 348. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-87590-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-87590-8"><bdi>978-1-136-87590-8</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-66"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-66">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGernet1996">Gernet, Jacques (31 May 1996). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historyofchinese00gern" rel="nofollow"><i>A History of Chinese Civilization</i></a></span>. Cambridge University Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/historyofchinese00gern/page/291" rel="nofollow">291</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-49781-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-49781-7"><bdi>978-0-521-49781-7</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 July</span> 2016</span>. <q>Korea held a dominant position in the north-eastern seas.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+History+of+Chinese+Civilization&amp;rft.pages=291&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1996-05-31&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-49781-7&amp;rft.aulast=Gernet&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacques&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fhistoryofchinese00gern&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-67">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFReischauer1955">Reischauer, Edwin Oldfather (1 May 1955). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=HXqEAAAACAAJ" rel="nofollow"><i>Ennins Travels in Tang China</i></a>. John Wiley &amp; Sons Canada, Limited. pp. 276–283. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-471-07053-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-471-07053-5"><bdi>978-0-471-07053-5</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 July</span> 2016</span>. <q>From what Ennin tells us, it seems that commerce between East China, Korea and Japan was, for the most part, in the hands of men from Silla. Here in the relatively dangerous waters on the eastern fringes of the world, they performed the same functions as did the traders of the placid Mediterranean on the western fringes. This is a historical fact of considerable significance but one which has received virtually no attention in the standard historical compilations of that period or in the modern books based on these sources. ... While there were limits to the influence of the Koreans along the eastern coast of China, there can be no doubt of their dominance over the waters off these shores. ... The days of Korean maritime dominance in the Far East actually were numbered, but in Ennin's time the men of Silla were still the masters of the seas in their part of the world.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ennins+Travels+in+Tang+China&amp;rft.pages=276-283&amp;rft.pub=John+Wiley+%26+Sons+Canada%2C+Limited&amp;rft.date=1955-05-01&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-471-07053-5&amp;rft.aulast=Reischauer&amp;rft.aufirst=Edwin+Oldfather&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DHXqEAAAACAAJ&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-68"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-68">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKim2014">Kim, Djun Kil (30 May 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=IgxvBAAAQBAJ&amp;q=%22Greater+Silla+dominated+the+Yellow+Sea%2C+the+East+China+Sea%2C+and+the+South+%28Korea%29+Sea+with+trade+between+Tang+China+and+Nara-Heian+Japan.%22" rel="nofollow"><i>The History of Korea, 2nd Edition</i></a>. ABC-CLIO. p. 3. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-61069-582-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-61069-582-4"><bdi>978-1-61069-582-4</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Koryo3-84"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Koryo3_84-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKim2005">Kim, Djun Kil (30 January 2005). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=ci_iGuAAqmsC&amp;pg=PA57" rel="nofollow"><i>The History of Korea</i></a>. <li id="cite_note-Koryo4-85"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Koryo4_85-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFGrayson2013">Grayson, James H. (5 November 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=LU78AQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA79" rel="nofollow"><i>Korea – A Religious History</i></a>. Routledge. p. 79. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-136-86925-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-136-86925-9"><bdi>978-1-136-86925-9</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 November</span> 2016</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korea+%E2%80%93+A+Religious+History&amp;rft.pages=79&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013-11-05&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-136-86925-9&amp;rft.aulast=Grayson&amp;rft.aufirst=James+H.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DLU78AQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPA79&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-86"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-86">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLee1984">Lee, Ki-Baik (1984). <i>A New History of Korea</i>. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. p. 103. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-674-61576-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-674-61576-2"><bdi>978-0-674-61576-2</bdi></a>. <q>When Parhae perished at the hands of the Khitan around this same time, much of its ruling class, who were of Koguryŏ descent, fled to Koryŏ. Wang Kŏn warmly welcomed them and generously gave them land. Along with bestowing the name Wang Kye ("Successor of the Royal Wang") on the Parhae crown prince, Tae Kwang-hyŏn, Wang Kŏn entered his name in the royal household register, thus clearly conveying the idea that they belonged to the same lineage, and also had rituals performed in honor of his progenitor. Thus Koryŏ achieved a true national unification that embraced not only the Later Three Kingdoms but even survivors of Koguryŏ lineage from the Parhae kingdom.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+New+History+of+Korea&amp;rft.place=Cambridge&amp;rft.pages=103&amp;rft.pub=Harvard+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-674-61576-2&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Ki-Baik&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLee1997">Lee, Kenneth B. <li id="cite_note-90"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-90">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBowman2000">Bowman, John (5 September 2000). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/columbiachronolo00john" rel="nofollow"><i>Columbia Chronologies of Asian History and Culture</i></a></span>. Columbia University Press. p. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/columbiachronolo00john/page/202" rel="nofollow">202</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-231-50004-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-231-50004-3"><bdi>978-0-231-50004-3</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 August</span> 2016</span>. <q>The Mongolian-Khitan invasions of the late tenth century challenge the stability of the Koryo government, but a period of prosperity follows the defeat of the Khitan in 1018..</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Columbia+Chronologies+of+Asian+History+and+Culture&amp;rft.pages=202&amp;rft.pub=Columbia+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2000-09-05&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-231-50004-3&amp;rft.aulast=Bowman&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fcolumbiachronolo00john&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-104">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Regarding Syngman Rhee (South Korea):<div><ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLee2005">Lee, Gil-sang (2005). <i>Korea through the Ages</i>. Seongnam: Center for Information on Korean Culture, the Academy of Korean Studies. pp. 166–181.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korea+through+the+Ages&amp;rft.place=Seongnam&amp;rft.pages=166-181&amp;rft.pub=Center+for+Information+on+Korean+Culture%2C+the+Academy+of+Korean+Studies&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Gil-sang&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLeeParkYoon2005">Lee, Hyun-hee; Park, Sung-soo; Yoon, Nae-hyun (2005). <i>New History of Korea</i>. Paju: Jimoondang. pp. 584–590.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=New+History+of+Korea&amp;rft.place=Paju&amp;rft.pages=584-590&amp;rft.pub=Jimoondang&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.aulast=Lee&amp;rft.aufirst=Hyun-hee&amp;rft.au=Park%2C+Sung-soo&amp;rft.au=Yoon%2C+Nae-hyun&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul></div>Regarding Kim Il-sung (North Korea):<div><ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBuzo2002">Buzo, Adrian (2002). <i>The Making of Modern Korea</i>. London: Routledge. pp. 71–91. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-23749-9" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-23749-9"><bdi>978-0-415-23749-9</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Making+of+Modern+Korea&amp;rft.place=London&amp;rft.pages=71-91&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-23749-9&amp;rft.aulast=Buzo&amp;rft.aufirst=Adrian&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li></ul></div></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAppleman1998">Appleman, Roy E. (1998) [1961]. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140207235336/http://www.history.army.mil/books/korea/20-2-1/toc.htm" rel="nofollow"><i>South to the Naktong, North to the Yalu</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Center_of_Military_History" title="United States Army Center of Military History">United States Army Center of Military History</a>. p. 17. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0160019180" title="Special:BookSources/978-0160019180"><bdi>978-0160019180</bdi></a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.history.army.mil/books/korea/20-2-1/toc.htm" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 7 February 2014.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=South+to+the+Naktong%2C+North+to+the+Yalu&amp;rft.pages=17&amp;rft.pub=United+States+Army+Center+of+Military+History&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rft.isbn=978-0160019180&amp;rft.aulast=Appleman&amp;rft.aufirst=Roy+E.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.history.army.mil%2Fbooks%2Fkorea%2F20-2-1%2Ftoc.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-106"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-106">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFMillett2007">Millett, Allan R. (2007). <i>The Korean War: The Essential Bibliography</i>. The Essential Bibliography Series. Dulles, VA: Potomac Books Inc. p. 14. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1574889765" title="Special:BookSources/978-1574889765"><bdi>978-1574889765</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Korean+War%3A+The+Essential+Bibliography&amp;rft.place=Dulles%2C+VA&amp;rft.series=The+Essential+Bibliography+Series&amp;rft.pages=14&amp;rft.pub=Potomac+Books+Inc.&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft.isbn=978-1574889765&amp;rft.aulast=Millett&amp;rft.aufirst=Allan+R.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-107"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-107">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFStuecker2004">Stuecker, William (2004). <i>Korean War: World History</i>. University Press of Kentucky. pp. 102–103.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korean+War%3A+World+History&amp;rft.pages=102-103&amp;rft.pub=University+Press+of+Kentucky&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.aulast=Stuecker&amp;rft.aufirst=William&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Hwang93-108"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Hwang93_108-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Su-kyoung Hwang, <i>Korea's Grievous War.</i> Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2016; pg. 90–95.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Kim_p.45-109"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Kim_p.45_109-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFKim2014">Kim, Samuel S. (2014). "The Evolving Asian System". <i>International Relations of Asia</i>. <a href="/wiki/Rowman_%26_Littlefield" title="Rowman &amp; Littlefield">Rowman &amp; Littlefield</a>. p. 45. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-2641-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4422-2641-8"><bdi>978-1-4422-2641-8</bdi></a>. <q>With three of the four major Cold War fault lines—divided Germany, divided Korea, divided China, and divided Vietnam—East Asia acquired the dubious distinction of having engendered the largest number of armed conflicts resulting in higher fatalities between 1945 and 1994 than any other region or sub-region. Even in Asia, while Central and South Asia produced a regional total of 2.8 million in human fatalities, East Asia's regional total is 10.4 million including the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Civil_War" title="Chinese Civil War">Chinese Civil War</a> (1 million), the Korean War (3 million), the <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">Vietnam War</a> (2 million), and the <a href="/wiki/Pol_Pot" title="Pol Pot">Pol Pot</a> <a href="/wiki/Cambodian_genocide" title="Cambodian genocide">genocide</a> in Cambodia (1 to 2 million).</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=The+Evolving+Asian+System&amp;rft.btitle=International+Relations+of+Asia&amp;rft.pages=45&amp;rft.pub=Rowman+%26+Littlefield&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4422-2641-8&amp;rft.aulast=Kim&amp;rft.aufirst=Samuel+S.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Cumings_p._35-110"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Cumings_p._35_110-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCumings2011"><a href="/wiki/Bruce_Cumings" title="Bruce Cumings">Cumings, Bruce</a> (2011). <i>The Korean War: A History</i>. <a href="/wiki/Modern_Library" title="Modern Library">Modern Library</a>. p. 35. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-8129-7896-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-8129-7896-4"><bdi>978-0-8129-7896-4</bdi></a>. <q>Various encyclopedias state that the countries involved in the three-year conflict suffered a total of more than 4 million casualties, of which at least 2 million were civilians—a higher percentage than in World War II or Vietnam. A total of 36,940 Americans lost their lives in the Korean theater; of these, 33,665 were killed in action, while 3,275 died there of nonhostile causes. Some 92,134 Americans were wounded in action, and decades later, 8,176 were still reported as missing. South Korea sustained 1,312,836 casualties, including 415,004 dead. Casualties among other UN allies totaled 16,532, including 3,094 dead. Estimated North Korean casualties numbered 2 million, including about one million civilians and 520,000 soldiers. An estimated 900,000 Chinese soldiers lost their lives in combat.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Korean+War%3A+A+History&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.pub=Modern+Library&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-8129-7896-4&amp;rft.aulast=Cumings&amp;rft.aufirst=Bruce&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Lewy_pp._450-453-111"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Lewy_pp._450-453_111-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFLewy1980"><a href="/wiki/Guenter_Lewy" title="Guenter Lewy">Lewy, Guenter</a> (1980). <a href="/wiki/America_in_Vietnam" title="America in Vietnam"><i>America in Vietnam</i></a>. <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University_Press" title="Oxford University Press">Oxford University Press</a>. pp. <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/americainvietnam00lewy/page/450" rel="nofollow">450</a>–453. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-19-987423-1" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-19-987423-1"><bdi>978-0-19-987423-1</bdi></a>. <q>The total number of Korean civilians who died in the fighting, which left almost every major city in North and South Korea in ruins, has been estimated at between 2 and 3 million. This adds up to almost 1 million military deaths and a possible 2.5 million civilians who were killed or died as a result of this extremely destructive conflict.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=America+in+Vietnam&amp;rft.pages=450-453&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1980&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-19-987423-1&amp;rft.aulast=Lewy&amp;rft.aufirst=Guenter&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-112"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-112">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/752055.stm" rel="nofollow">Flashback: The Kwangju massacre</a>, 17 May 2000.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-113"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-113">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/184219.html" rel="nofollow">"20 years later, father still seeks truth in son's death"</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160303173203/http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/184219.html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> 3 March 2016 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>, <i>The Hankyoreh</i>, 15 January 2007. <li id="cite_note-122"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-122">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFGladstone2021">Gladstone, Rick (4 January 2021). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/04/world/asia/south-korea-population.html" rel="nofollow">"As Birthrate Falls, South Korea's Population Declines, Posing Threat to Economy"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">5 January</span> 2021</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=As+Birthrate+Falls%2C+South+Korea%27s+Population+Declines%2C+Posing+Threat+to+Economy&amp;rft.date=2021-01-04&amp;rft.aulast=Gladstone&amp;rft.aufirst=Rick&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2021%2F01%2F04%2Fworld%2Fasia%2Fsouth-korea-population.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-124"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-124">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The estimated area rises steadily from year to year, possibly because of land reclamation. <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1 cs1-prop-script cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20040917181709/http://kosis.nso.go.kr/cgi-bin/sws_999.cgi?ID=DT_1A1&amp;IDTYPE=3&amp;A_LANG=1&amp;FPUB=3&amp;SELITEM=" rel="nofollow"><bdi lang="ko">행정구역(구시군)별 국토적</bdi></a>. <i>Korea Statistical Information Service</i> (in Korean). <li id="cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-141"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_141-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGranthamDuncanEvansJones2020">Grantham, H. S.;  et al. (2020). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7723057" rel="nofollow">"Anthropogenic modification of forests means only 40% of remaining forests have high ecosystem integrity – Supplementary Material"</a>. <i>Nature Communications</i>. <b>11</b> (1): 5978. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fs41467-020-19493-3" rel="nofollow">10.1038/s41467-020-19493-3</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33293507" rel="nofollow">33293507</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" <li id="cite_note-210"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-210">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080913195801/http://english.chosun.com/w21data/html/news/200809/200809110016.html" rel="nofollow">"Korea's Muslims Mark Ramadan"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Chosun_Ilbo" title="The Chosun Ilbo">The Chosun Ilbo</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-232"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-232">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFJung_Sung-ki2010">Jung Sung-ki (13 September 2010). <a class="external text" href="https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/09/205_72997.html" rel="nofollow">"Seoul reaffirms N. Korea's torpedo attack in final report"</a>. <i>The Korea Times</i>. <li id="cite_note-248"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-248">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/south-korea-russia-to-begin-preparations-for-fta-negotiations-moon" rel="nofollow">"South Korea, Russia to begin preparations for FTA negotiations: Moon"</a>. <i>The Straits Times</i>. 22 June 2018.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Straits+Times&amp;rft.atitle=South+Korea%2C+Russia+to+begin+preparations+for+FTA+negotiations%3A+Moon&amp;rft.date=2018-06-22&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fasia%2Feast-asia%2Fsouth-korea-russia-to-begin-preparations-for-fta-negotiations-moon&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-249"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-249">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A Brief History of the US-Korea Relations Prior to 1945. "While less than 100 Koreans in America enlisted in the US military during World War II, more than 100,000 Koreans served in the Japanese army as officers and soldiers. There were two Korean Lt. Generals in the Japanese Army: a Chosun prince, whose rank was honorary and who commanded no troops; and Lt. Gen. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hong_Sa-Ik" title="Hong Sa-Ik">Hong Sa-Ik</a>, who was a professional military man from the old Chosun army."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-250"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-250">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20090214033600/http://gangje.go.kr/admin_view0305.asp?idx=711&amp;page=1" rel="nofollow">"Truth Commission on Forced Mobilization under the japanese Imperialism Republic of Korea"</a>. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.gangje.go.kr/admin_view0305.asp?idx=711&amp;page=1" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 14 February 2009<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">18 March</span> 2009</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Truth+Commission+on+Forced+Mobilization+under+the+japanese+Imperialism+Republic+of+Korea.&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gangje.go.kr%2Fadmin_view0305.asp%3Fidx%3D711%26page%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-251"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-251">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSoh2001"><a href="/wiki/Chunghee_Sarah_Soh" title="Chunghee Sarah Soh">Soh, C. Sarah</a> (May 2001). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.today/20120628222046/http://www.jpri.org/publications/workingpapers/wp77.html" rel="nofollow">"Japan's Responsibility Toward Comfort Women Survivors"</a>. San Francisco: Japan Policy Research Institute. Archived from <a class="external text" href="http://www.jpri.org/publications/workingpapers/wp77.html" rel="nofollow">the original</a> on 28 June 2012<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">3 February</span> 2012</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Japan%27s+Responsibility+Toward+Comfort+Women+Survivors&amp;rft.place=San+Francisco&amp;rft.pub=Japan+Policy+Research+Institute&amp;rft.date=2001-05&amp;rft.aulast=Soh&amp;rft.aufirst=C.+Sarah&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.jpri.org%2Fpublications%2Fworkingpapers%2Fwp77.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-270"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-270">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/8army.htm" rel="nofollow">"Eighth United States Army (EUSA)"</a>. GlobalSecurity.org. 27 December 2005<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 February</span> 2010</span>. <q>The KATUSA Program is significant not only because of the military manpower and monetary savings that it provides to the U.S. Army, but also because it represents ROK/U.S. cooperation and commitment to deter war. The KATUSA Program is symbolic of ROK/U.S. friendship and mutual support.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Eighth+United+States+Army+%28EUSA%29&amp;rft.pub=GlobalSecurity.org&amp;rft.date=2005-12-27&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.globalsecurity.org%2Fmilitary%2Fagency%2Farmy%2F8army.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-372"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-372">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFRoberto_A._FerdmanRitchie_King2014">Roberto A. Ferdman; Ritchie King (2 February 2014). <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140208074557/http://qz.com/171191/south-koreans-drink-twice-as-much-liquor-as-russians-and-more-than-four-times-as-much-as-americans/" rel="nofollow">"South Koreans drink twice as much liquor as Russians and more than four times as much as Americans"</a>. <i>Quartz</i>. <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>

<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAmsden,_Alice1992">Amsden, Alice (1992). <i>Asia's Next Giant: South Korea and Late Industrialization</i>. Oxford University Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0195076035" title="Special:BookSources/978-0195076035"><bdi>978-0195076035</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Asia%27s+Next+Giant%3A+South+Korea+and+Late+Industrialization&amp;rft.pub=Oxford+University+Press&amp;rft.date=1992&amp;rft.isbn=978-0195076035&amp;rft.au=Amsden%2C+Alice&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBreen,_Michael2004"><a href="/wiki/Michael_Breen_(author)" title="Michael Breen (author)">Breen, Michael</a> (2004). <a href="/wiki/The_Koreans_(book)" title="The Koreans (book)"><i>The Koreans: Who They Are, What They Want, Where Their Future Lies</i></a>. St. Martin's Griffin. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-312-32609-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-312-32609-8"><bdi>978-0-312-32609-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Koreans%3A+Who+They+Are%2C+What+They+Want%2C+Where+Their+Future+Lies&amp;rft.pub=St.+Martin%27s+Griffin&amp;rft.date=2004&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-312-32609-8&amp;rft.au=Breen%2C+Michael&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFHart,_Dennis2003">Hart, Dennis (2003). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/fromtraditiontoc00hart" rel="nofollow"><i>From Tradition to Consumption: Constructing a Capitalist Culture in South Korea</i></a>. Seoul: Author. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-89-88095-44-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-89-88095-44-7"><bdi>978-89-88095-44-7</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=From+Tradition+to+Consumption%3A+Constructing+a+Capitalist+Culture+in+South+Korea&amp;rft.place=Seoul&amp;rft.pub=Author&amp;rft.date=2003&amp;rft.isbn=978-89-88095-44-7&amp;rft.au=Hart%2C+Dennis&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Ffromtraditiontoc00hart&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFCumings,_Bruce1997">Cumings, Bruce (1997). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/koreasplaceinsun00bruc" rel="nofollow"><i>Korea's place in the sun</i></a></span>. New York: W.W. Norton. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-393-31681-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-393-31681-0"><bdi>978-0-393-31681-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Korea%27s+place+in+the+sun&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft.pub=W.W.+Norton&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-393-31681-0&amp;rft.au=Cumings%2C+Bruce&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fkoreasplaceinsun00bruc&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASouth+Korea"></span></li>
